revision.text:
{{Year box}} '''1858 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[Baseball]]== '''National championship''' * [[National Association of Base Ball Players]] champion – [[New York Mutuals]] '''Events''' * "All New York" and "All Brooklyn" Nines play three matches at the Fashion Race Course in [[Queens]], with the All New York Nine winning the first and third. The series is a great leap forward for commercial baseball.
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * 5 January — [[Tom Sayers]] defeats [[Bill Benjamin]] in only three rounds at the Isle of Grain and now challenges [[Tom Paddock]] for the undisputed Championship of England.<ref name="TS">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/sayers.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – Tom Sayers]. Retrieved on 8 November 2009.</ref> * 16 June — Sayers and Paddock finally meet at Canvey Island where Sayers wins in 21 rounds to become the undisputed English champion.<ref name="TS"/> * 20 October — [[John Morrissey]] at last defends the Championship of America at Long Point in Canada against [[John C. Heenan]]. Heenan breaks two knuckles early in the fight which ends after the 11th round with Heenan unable to continue.<ref name="JM">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/morrisey.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – John Morrissey]. Retrieved on 8 November 2009.</ref>
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * [[John Jackson (cricketer, born 1833)|John Jackson]]'s season tally of 102 known wickets is a new record and he is the first bowler credited with 100 in a [[first-class cricket|first-class]] season '''England''' * Most runs – [[William Caffyn]] 516 @ 21.50 (HS 102) * Most wickets – [[John Jackson (cricketer, born 1833)|John Jackson]] 102 @ 11.03 (BB 9–27)
==[[Football]]== '''Events''' * [[Blackheath Rugby Club]] founded. It claims to be the world's oldest "open" [[rugby football]] club given that [[Liverpool St Helens FC|Liverpool FC]] (see [[1857 in sports]]) is no longer a single entity. * [[Edinburgh Academicals RFC]] is founded and is the oldest football club (all codes) in Scotland. * 21 October — first written version of the [[Sheffield Rules]] is introduced at the first annual general meeting of [[Sheffield FC]] for use in its matches
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[1858 Grand National|Grand National]] – Little Charley * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – Governess * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – Fitz-Roland * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Beadsman (horse)|Beadsman]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – Governess * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – Sunbeam
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * 27 March — [[Cambridge University Boat Club|Cambridge]] wins the 15th [[The Boat Race 1858|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]]
;Other * 26 May — Brown, Harvard, Trinity, and Yale boat clubs confer as the College Regatta Association but it never conducts a championship
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Infobox international football competition | tourney_name = African Cup of Nations | year = 1962 | other_titles = | image = | size = 200px | alt = | caption = | country = Ethiopia | country-flagvar = 1897 | dates = 14 – 21 January | num_teams = 4 | confederations = 1 | associations = | venues = 1 | cities = 1 | champion = Ethiopia | champion-flagvar = 1897 | count = 1 | second = United Arab Republic | second-flagvar = | third = Tunisia | third-flagvar = | fourth = Uganda | fourth-flagvar = colonial | matches = 4 | goals = 18 | attendance = | top_scorer = {{flagicon|UAR}} [[Badawi Abdel Fattah]]
{{flagicon|ETH|1897}} [[Mengistu Worku]]
(3 goals each) | player = {{flagicon|ETH|1897}} [[Mengistu Worku]] | prevseason = [[1959 African Cup of Nations|1959]] | nextseason = [[1963 African Cup of Nations|1963]] }} [[Image:African Cup of Nations 1962.png|thumb|Participating nations]] The '''1962 African Cup of Nations''' was the third edition of the [[Africa Cup of Nations]], the [[soccer]] championship of Africa ([[Confederation of African Football|CAF]]). It was hosted by [[Ethiopia]]. Nine countries entered the competition, including the reigning champions [[Egypt national football team|Egypt]], meaning for the first time a qualification tournament was required. The finals only included four teams. Egypt, as holders, and [[Ethiopia national football team|Ethiopia]] as hosts, qualified automatically meaning each needed to play only one game to reach the final. Ethiopia won the tournament for the first time after [[extra time]] in the final.{{cite web | last = Thomas | first = Durosimi | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/20016125 | title = New dawn for Ethiopia after Nations Cup qualification | publisher = BBC Sport | date = 2012-10-20 | accessdate = 2013-05-27}} This tournament has the highest goals-per-game average in Africa Cup of Nations tournaments. ==Qualified teams== {{Qualification for championships (CAF)}} This page details the process of '''qualifying''' for the '''1962 African Cup of Nations'''. 9 African nations initially entered the competition. Ethiopia and Egypt both automatically qualified as the host country and title holders respectively. Morocco would withdraw before play began, thus leaving only 6 teams vying for the remaining two spots in the finals. ==Qualified teams== {{main|1962 African Cup of Nations qualification}} {{Clear}} {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:left;" |- ! {{Infobox NRHP | name = Aztec Bowl | nrhp_type = | partof = San Diego State College | partof_refnum = 97000924 | image = Aztecbowl.JPG | caption = Aztec Bowl | location= 5300 Campanile Dr.,
[[San Diego]], [[California]] | coordinates = {{coord|32|46|33|N|117|4|16|W|display=inline,title}} | locmapin = USA California San Diego County#USA California#USA | area = | architect = multiple | architecture = Mission/Spanish Revival | added = September 4, 1997{{NRISref|2009a}} | governing_body = State | refnum = 94000402{{NRISref|version=2010a}} }} '''Aztec Bowl''' was a [[American football|football]] stadium (a [[Works Progress Administration]] project) on the [[San Diego State University]] campus in [[San Diego]], [[California]]. ==History== Aztec Bowl hosted the [[San Diego State University]] [[San Diego State Aztecs football|Aztecs]] [[College football|football]] team until they moved to [[Qualcomm Stadium]] in 1967. The stadium held 12,592 people at its peak and cost $500,000 to build. It was dedicated on October 3, 1936 before 7,500 people, after being completed earlier that year. The stadium was initially supposed to be expanded to 45,000 seats but was expanded only once, to 5,000 seats in 1948. ==Current use== Currently [[Viejas Arena]] (formerly Cox Arena), the school's basketball arena, sits on the site of the stadium. ==National Register of Historic Places== Aztec Bowl is listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]]:{{cite web|url=http://dometest.sdsu.edu/projects/buildings/bldgs.html|title=Historic Buildings of San Diego State University|work=Infodome - SDSU Historic Buildings|publisher=San Diego State University|accessdate=2009-07-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060906094946/http://dometest.sdsu.edu/projects/buildings/bldgs.html|archive-date=2006-09-06|dead-url=yes|df=}} The old concrete bleachers of the football stadium were not demolished when the new arena was built. [[John F. Kennedy]], then the [[President of the United States|President of the United States of America]], gave the graduation commencement address at San Diego State University on June 6, 1963.[http://sdsuniverse.info/story.asp?id=6269 Forty Years Later, the Magic of JFK Lingers on the Mesa] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070706133627/http://sdsuniverse.info/story.asp?id=6269 |date=2007-07-06 }}, Coleen L. Geraghty, ''SDSUniverse'' (May 12, 2003){{Cite web |url=http://infodome.sdsu.edu/projects/buildings/aztecbowl.html |title=''SDSU Library'', Aztec Bowl: History of San Diego State University (accessed Jan. 16, 2009) |access-date=2008-11-30 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721003154/http://infodome.sdsu.edu/projects/buildings/aztecbowl.html |archive-date=2011-07-21 |dead-url=yes |df= }}[http://scua.sdsu.edu/exhibits/online/2010/03/JFKMovie/JFKMovie.shtml John F. Kennedy commencement address (June 6, 1963), SDSU Special Collections (video)][http://library.sdsu.edu/scua/exhibits-and-events/online-exhibits/kennedy|San Diego State University, Library & Information Access, "President John F. Kennedy's 1963 Commencement Speech at San Diego State (video and audio archive)] {{quote|As a nation, we have no deeper concern, no older commitment and no higher interest than a strong, sound and free system of education for all. In fulfilling this obligation to ourselves and our children, we provide for the future of our nation-and for the future of freedom.
[http://library.sdsu.edu/scua/exhibits-and-events/online-exhibits/kennedy (Historical Video)] |sign=[[John F. Kennedy]], [[President of the United States|President of the United States of America]], Graduation commencement address to San Diego State College (San Diego, California), June 6, 1963}}. In commemoration, the arena was built on top of the steps from which people listened to President Kennedy. The bleachers can be clearly seen from the arena's parking lot on the outside and in the storage areas under the arena seats on the inside of the arena. There has been a request to remove the stadium from the National Register of Historic Places.{{Cite web | title = Pending (Not Yet Acted Upon) List | work = | publisher = [[National Park Service]] | date =April 21, 2012 | url = http://www.nps.gov/history/nr/pending/P20120421.htm | accessdate = 27 April 2012}} ==See also== * [[Viejas Arena]] * [[Peterson Gym]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110721003154/http://infodome.sdsu.edu/projects/buildings/aztecbowl.html Venue information] {{San Diego State Aztecs football navbox}} {{National Register of Historic Places}} [[Category:Defunct college football venues]] [[Category:San Diego State Aztecs football venues]] [[Category:Sports venues in San Diego]] [[Category:American football venues in California]] [[Category:Works Progress Administration in California]] [[Category:University and college buildings on the National Register of Historic Places in California]] [[Category:Demolished sports venues in California]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1936]] [[Category:1936 establishments in California]] [[Category:North American Soccer League (1968–84) stadiums]] [[Category:National Register of Historic Places in San Diego County, California]] [[Category:Sports venues on the National Register of Historic Places in California]]

{{italic title}} {{Use mdy dates|date=September 2016}} {{Infobox film | name = Battle of the Sexes | image = Battle of the Sexes (film).png | alt = The upper half of the poster shows a sepia toned image, of a man and a woman speaking at before a bank of microphones. Below a tennis ball. | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Jonathan Dayton and Valerie Faris|Jonathan Dayton
Valerie Faris]] | producer = {{Plainlist| * [[Christian Colson]] * [[Danny Boyle]] * Robert Graf }} | writer = [[Simon Beaufoy]] | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Emma Stone]] * [[Steve Carell]] * [[Andrea Riseborough]] * [[Sarah Silverman]] * [[Bill Pullman]] * [[Alan Cumming]] * [[Elisabeth Shue]] }} | music = [[Nicholas Britell]] | cinematography = [[Linus Sandgren]] | editing = [[Pamela Martin (film editor)|Pamela Martin]] | studio = {{Plainlist| * Decibel Films * [[Cloud Eight Films]] }} | distributor = [[Fox Searchlight Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|2017|9|2|[[Telluride Film Festival|Telluride]]|2017|9|22|United States}} | runtime = 121 minutes{{cite web|url=http://www.tiff.net/tiff/film.html?v=battle-of-the-sexes|title=Battle of the Sexes|work=[[Toronto International Film Festival]]|accessdate=July 26, 2017}}{{cite web | url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/battle-sexes-film | title=''BATTLE OF THE SEXES'' | work=[[British Board of Film Classification]]}} Retrieved September 6, 2017 | country = {{ubl|United Kingdom|United States}} | language = English | budget = $25 million{{Cite web|url=https://www.mpaa.org/press/production-of-fox-searchlights-battle-of-the-sexes-contributed-over-25-million-to-the-california-economy/|title=Production of Fox Searchlight's Battle of the Sexes Contributed Over $25 Million to the California Economy|date=September 21, 2017|website=[[MPAA]]|accessdate=September 29, 2017}} | gross = $18.4 million{{cite web |url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movie/Battle-of-the-Sexes-(2017)#tab=box-office|title=Battle of the Sexes (2017) |website=[[The Numbers (website)|The Numbers]]|accessdate=July 2, 2018}} }} '''''Battle of the Sexes''''' is a 2017 [[Biographical film|biographical]] [[sports film]] directed by [[Jonathan Dayton and Valerie Faris]] and written by [[Simon Beaufoy]]. The plot is loosely based on the [[Battle of the Sexes (tennis)#1973: Riggs v King|1973 tennis match]] between [[Billie Jean King]] and [[Bobby Riggs]]. The film stars [[Emma Stone]] and [[Steve Carell]] as King and Riggs, with [[Andrea Riseborough]], [[Elisabeth Shue]], [[Austin Stowell]], [[Bill Pullman]], [[Natalie Morales (actress)|Natalie Morales]], and [[Sarah Silverman]] in supporting roles. The film had its premiere at the [[Telluride Film Festival]] on September 2, 2017, and was theatrically released in the United States by [[Fox Searchlight Pictures]] on September 22, 2017.{{Cite news|url=http://deadline.com/2017/08/london-film-festival-battle-of-the-sexes-gala-european-premiere-emma-stone-billie-jean-king-1202149086/|title=London Film Festival To Serve ‘Battle Of The Sexes’ In Gala European Premiere|last=Tartaglione|first=Nancy|date=2017-08-15|work=Deadline|access-date=2017-09-25|language=en-US}} It received positive reviews from critics, who praised the performances of Stone and Carell and the direction, with some calling it the best performance of Stone's career. Despite the positive reviews, the film was a box office disappointment, grossing $18.4 million against a $25 million budget. At the [[75th Golden Globe Awards]], Stone and Carell received nominations for [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actress – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy|Best Actress – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy]] and [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actor – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy|Best Actor – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy]] respectively.{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2017/film/news/golden-globe-nominations-2018-nominees-full-list-1202634435/|title=Golden Globe Nominations: Complete List|work=Variety|date=December 11, 2017|accessdate=December 11, 2017|first=Rebecca|last=Rubin}} At the [[24th Screen Actors Guild Awards]], both received [[Critics Choice Awards]] nominations in the categories [[Critics' Choice Movie Award for Best Actress in a Comedy|Best Actress in a Comedy]] and [[Critics' Choice Movie Award for Best Actor in a Comedy|Best Actor in a Comedy]]. Carell also received a nomination for [[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Male Actor in a Supporting Role|Outstanding Performance by a Male Actor in a Supporting Role]]. ==Plot== The film dramatizes the events leading up to the September 1973 match between [[Billie Jean King]] and [[Bobby Riggs]], and their personal lives. In 1970, King and [[Gladys Heldman]] confront [[Jack Kramer]], who has organized a tennis tournament where the top prize for women is one-eighth of the men's prize, despite equal ticket sales. King and Heldman threaten to start their own tour but Kramer won't alter the terms, citing the inferiority of women's tennis. When Billie Jean, [[Julie Heldman]], [[Valerie Ziegenfuss]], [[Judy Dalton]], [[Kristy Pigeon]], [[Peaches Bartkowicz]], [[Kerry Melville Reid]], [[Nancy Richey]], and [[Rosie Casals]] sign on as the “Original 9” players of what becomes the [[Virginia Slims Circuit]], Kramer bans them from tournaments organized by the [[United States Tennis Association|US Lawn Tennis Association]]. While the women's tour struggles during its early days, Billie Jean begins an affair with Marilyn Barnett, her hairdresser, threatening her marriage to [[Larry King (tennis)|Larry King]]. Meanwhile, Riggs' marriage to the [[United Cigar Stores|wealthy Priscilla (Whelan) Riggs]] is in trouble because of his addiction to gambling. Thrown out of his house when he can't conceal a Rolls Royce he won in a tennis bet, he hits upon the idea of a challenge match against the top woman player, boasting that even at age 55 he can beat any woman. The women's tour has slowly gained a stronger foothold, with the [[Women's Tennis Association]] formed in 1973. Riggs continues to pressure King to play him. Eventually, Riggs persuades [[Margaret Court]], who recently overtook King to gain the [[World number 1 ranked female tennis players|World No. 1 ranking]], to play a match in May 1973. Riggs [[Battle of the Sexes (tennis)#1973: Riggs vs. Court|easily defeats Court]] and King decides she has to accept his challenge, but demands a final say as to the arrangements. King trains intensely, while Riggs relaxes. King objects to Kramer as a game announcer, threatening to not play unless he withdraws, which he does. After a slow start, King wins the match and Riggs reunites with his wife. == Cast == {{div col}} * [[Emma Stone]] as [[Billie Jean King]] * [[Steve Carell]] as [[Bobby Riggs]] * [[Andrea Riseborough]] as Marilyn Barnett * [[Sarah Silverman]] as [[Gladys Heldman]] * [[Bill Pullman]] as [[Jack Kramer]] * [[Alan Cumming]] as [[Ted Tinling|Cuthbert "Ted" Tinling]] * [[Elisabeth Shue]] as Priscilla Riggs * [[Austin Stowell]] as [[Larry King (tennis)|Larry King]] * [[Natalie Morales (actress)|Natalie Morales]] as [[Rosemary Casals|Rosie Casals]] (“Original 9”) * [[Jessica McNamee]] as [[Margaret Court]] * [[Fred Armisen]] as Rheo Blair * [[Lewis Pullman]] as Larry Riggs * [[Martha MacIsaac]] as [[Jane Bartkowicz|Jane “Peaches” Bartkowicz]] (“Original 9”) * [[Mickey Sumner]] as [[Valerie Ziegenfuss]] (“Original 9”) * [[Bridey Elliott]] as [[Julie Heldman]] (“Original 9”) * [[Eric Christian Olsen]] as Lornie Kuhle * [[Wallace Langham]] as Henry * [[Matt Malloy]] as Rigg's Therapist * [[James Mackay (actor)|James Mackay]] as Barry Court * Lauren Kline as [[Nancy Richey]] (“Original 9”) * [[Ashley Weinhold]] as [[Kristy Pigeon]] (“Original 9”) * Fidan Manashirova as [[Judy Tegart-Dalton|Judy Tegart Dalton]] (“Original 9”) * [[Kaitlyn Christian]] as [[Kerry Melville|Kerry Melville Reid]] (“Original 9”) {{div col end}} == Production == The project and its two leads were announced in April 2015.{{cite news|last1=Fleming Jr|first1=Mike|title=Game, Set Match? Searchlight Serves Up ‘Battle Of The Sexes;’ Dayton & Faris Direct Emma Stone As Billie Jean King, Steve Carell As Bobby Riggs|url=http://deadline.com/2015/04/battle-of-the-sexes-emma-stone-billie-jean-king-steve-carell-bobby-riggs-fox-searchlight-1201412970/|accessdate=September 20, 2015|work=deadline.com|date=April 20, 2015}} [[Brie Larson]] was, for a brief period, set to replace Stone due to scheduling conflicts, but these were cleared up.{{cite news|last1=Kroll|first1=Justin|title=Brie Larson in Talks to Play Billie Jean King in ‘Battle of the Sexes’ (EXCLUSIVE)|url=https://variety.com/2015/film/news/brie-larson-billie-jean-king-battle-of-the-sexes-1201596967/|accessdate=September 20, 2015|work=variety.com|date=September 18, 2015}}{{cite news|last1=Kroll|first1=Justin|title=Emma Stone Set to Star as Billie Jean King in Fox Searchlight’s ‘Battle of the Sexes’ (EXCLUSIVE)|url=https://variety.com/2015/film/news/battle-sexes-emma-stone-billie-jean-king-1201644084/|accessdate=November 29, 2015|work=variety.com|date=November 18, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160329123808/http://variety.com/2015/film/news/battle-sexes-emma-stone-billie-jean-king-1201644084/|archivedate=March 29, 2016|df=}} On March 3, 2016, [[Andrea Riseborough]] was cast to play Marilyn Barnett, King's hairdresser and lover.{{cite news|last1=Kroll|first1=Justin|title=‘Battle of the Sexes’ Adds Andrea Riseborough (EXCLUSIVE)|url=https://variety.com/2016/film/news/battle-sexes-andrea-riseborough-1201722351/|accessdate=March 26, 2016|work=Variety|date=March 3, 2016}} Later that month, three more were cast in the film, [[Elisabeth Shue]] as Riggs' wife;{{cite news|last1=Kroll|first1=Justin|title=Elisabeth Shue Joins Emma Stone in Fox Searchlight’s ‘Battle of the Sexes’ (EXCLUSIVE)|url=https://variety.com/2016/film/news/elisabeth-shue-battle-for-the-sexes-emma-stone-1201735645/|accessdate=March 26, 2016|work=Variety|date=March 21, 2016}} [[Austin Stowell]] as [[Larry King (tennis)|Larry King]], Billie Jean's husband;{{cite news|last1=A. Lincoln|first1=Ross|title=Austin Stowell Joins Billie Jean King Biopic ‘Battle Of The Sexes’ In Key Role|url=http://deadline.com/2016/03/austin-stowell-battle-of-the-sexes-billie-jean-king-biopic-1201724452/|accessdate=March 26, 2016|work=Deadline|date=March 22, 2016}} and [[Sarah Silverman]] as [[Gladys Heldman]], the founder of ''World Tennis'' magazine.{{cite news|last1=Hipes|first1=Patrick|title=Sarah Silverman A Match For ‘Battle Of The Sexes’|url=http://deadline.com/2016/03/sarah-silverman-battle-of-the-sexes-movie-gladys-heldman-1201725371/|accessdate=March 25, 2016|work=Deadline|date=March 23, 2016}} Four actors joined the cast in April: [[Eric Christian Olsen]] as Lornie Kuhle,{{cite news|last1=Lincoln|first1=Ross A.|title=Eric Christian Olsen Swings For ‘Battle Of The Sexes’; Talitha Bateman Joins ‘Vengeance: A Love Story’|url=http://deadline.com/2016/04/battle-of-the-sexes-eric-christian-olsen-talitha-bateman-vengeance-a-love-story-1201730137/|accessdate=April 14, 2016|work=Deadline|date=April 1, 2016}} [[Jessica McNamee]] as tennis player [[Margaret Court]],{{cite news|last1=Fleming, Jr.|first1=Mike|title=Jessica McNamee Plays Margaret Court In ‘Battle Of The Sexes’|url=http://deadline.com/2016/04/jessica-mcnamee-margaret-court-battle-of-the-sexes-bilie-jean-king-bobby-riggs-1201733072/|accessdate=April 14, 2016|work=Deadline|date=April 7, 2016}} [[Alan Cumming]] as designer [[Ted Tinling]],{{cite news|last1=Siegel|first1=Tatiana|title=Alan Cumming to Co-Star in Fox Searchlight's 'Battle of the Sexes'|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/alan-cumming-star-fox-searchlights-883311|accessdate=April 14, 2016|work=The Hollywood Reporter|date=April 12, 2016}} and [[Natalie Morales (actress)|Natalie Morales]] as player [[Rosemary Casals|Rosie Casals]].{{cite news|last1=Pedersen|first1=Erik|title=Natalie Morales Game For ‘Battle Of The Sexes’; Jimmy Smagula Books ‘Rebel In The Rye’|url=http://deadline.com/2016/04/natalie-morales-battle-of-the-sexes-jimmy-smagula-rebel-in-the-rye-1201736626/|accessdate=April 14, 2016|work=Deadline|date=April 13, 2016}} [[Principal photography]] on the film began in [[Los Angeles]] on April 13, 2016, with a budget of more than $25 million.{{cite news|last1=Evry|first1=Max|title=First Battle of the Sexes Photo as Filming Begins|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/movies/news/676181-first-battle-of-the-sexes-photo-as-filming-begins#/slide/1|accessdate=April 14, 2016|work=ComingSoon.net|date=April 13, 2016|language=en-US}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.mpaa.org/press/production-of-fox-searchlights-battle-of-the-sexes-contributed-over-25-million-to-the-california-economy/|title=PRODUCTION OF FOX SEARCHLIGHT’S BATTLE OF THE SEXES CONTRIBUTED OVER $25 MILLION TO THE CALIFORNIA ECONOMY|last=|first=|date=September 21, 2017|website=MPAA|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} For the tennis match scenes, tennis players [[Kaitlyn Christian]] (who portrays “Original 9” member [[Kerry Melville|Kerry Melville Reid]]) and [[Vince Spadea]] were the body doubles of Stone and Carell, respectively.{{cite web|url=http://baseline.tennis.com/article/69549/how-battle-sexes-made-tennis-look-real|title=How Battle of the Sexes Made the Tennis Look Real|first=Nina|last=Pantic|date=26 September 2017|accessdate=29 September 2017|work=Baseline}}{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/espnw/culture/article/20753181/how-emma-stone-picked-billie-jean-king-game-battle-sexes|title=How Emma Stone picked up Billie Jean King's game for 'Battle of the Sexes'|first=Katie|last=Barnes|publisher=ESPN|date=19 September 2017|accessdate=29 September 2017}} ==Release== ''Battle of the Sexes'' had its world premiere at the [[Telluride Film Festival]] on September 2, 2017.{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/08/telluride-film-festival-2017-lineup-list-batle-of-the-sexes-1202158843/|title=‘Darkest Hour’, ‘Battle Of The Sexes’, ‘Lady Bird’ Among World Premieres In 2017 Lineup – Telluride Film Festival|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|first=Pete|last=Hammond|date=August 31, 2017|accessdate=August 31, 2017}} It also screened at the [[Toronto International Film Festival]] on September 10, 2017,{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/07/toronto-film-festival-2017-margot-robbie-gary-oldman-jake-gyllenhaal-emma-stone-christian-bale-1202135285/ |title=Toronto Film Festival 2017 Unveils Strong Slate |work=Deadline |accessdate=July 25, 2017}} and at the [[BFI London Film Festival]] on October 7, 2017.{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2017/film/news/battle-of-the-sexes-emma-stone-steve-carrell-1202527868/ |title=London Film Festival Serves Up ‘Battle of the Sexes’ Gala Screening |author=Stewart Clarke. |work=Variety |date=August 15, 2017 |accessdate=2017-08-25}} The film began a limited release in the United States on September 22, 2017, before going wide the following week.{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/03/battle-of-the-sexes-emma-stone-steve-carell-1202047963/|title=‘Battle Of The Sexes’: Billie Jean King-Bobby Riggs Tennis Pic Sets Fall Date|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|first=Anthony|last=D'Alessandro|date=March 21, 2017|accessdate=March 21, 2017}} ===Box office=== ''Battle of the Sexes'' grossed $12.6 million in the United States and Canada, and $5.8 million in other territories, for a worldwide total of $18.4 million. In its opening weekend, the film grossed $515,450 from 21 theaters, an average of $24,545 per theater.{{cite web |url=http://deadline.com/2017/09/tom-cruise-emma-stone-american-made-battle-of-the-sexes-flatliners-weekend-box-office-1202179279/|title=‘It’ Breaks Three-Way Tie Battle, ‘Kingsman’ & ‘American Made’ Fight For Second |first=Anthony|last=D'Alessandro|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|accessdate=October 1, 2017}} The film expanded the following Friday, where it was released alongside the openings of ''[[Flatliners (2017 film)|Flatliners]]'', ''[['Til Death Do Us Part (film)|'Til Death Do Us Part]]'' and ''[[American Made (film)|American Made]]'', and was projected to gross around $6 million from 1,213 theaters over the weekend.{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/la-fi-ct-movie-projector-america-made-20170927-htmlstory.html|title='It' drives record September box office with Tom Cruise's 'American Made' ready to battle 'Kingsman'|website=[[Los Angeles Times]]|author=Ryan Faughnder|date=September 27, 2017|accessdate=September 27, 2017}} It ended up making $3.4 million over the weekend, finishing 6th at the box office. [[Deadline Hollywood]] noted the film's weekend gross was disappointing given its cast and positive reviews. The following week the film was added to another 609 theaters and made $2.4 million, dropping just 30%.{{Cite web |url=http://deadline.com/2017/10/blade-runner-2049-ryan-gosling-box-office-bomb-1202184297/|title=‘Blade Runner 2049’ Dulls -11% On Saturday; Weekend Opening Now At $31M+: Sunday Postmortem|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|accessdate=October 8, 2017}} ===Critical response=== On the review aggregation website [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film has an approval rating of 85% based on 268 reviews, with an average rating of 7.2/10. The site's critical consensus reads, "''Battle of the Sexes'' turns real-life events into a crowd-pleasing, well-acted dramedy that ably entertains while smartly serving up a volley of present-day parallels."{{cite web|url= https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/battle_of_the_sexes/ |title=''Battle of the Sexes'' (2017) |website=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |accessdate=March 11, 2018}} On [[Metacritic]], which assigns a normalized rating to reviews, the film a weighted average score of 73 out of 100, based on 46 critics, indicating "generally favorable reviews".{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/battle-of-the-sexes|title=''Battle of the Sexes'' reviews|website=[[Metacritic]]|accessdate=October 3, 2017}} Audiences polled by [[CinemaScore]] gave the film an average grade of "A" on an A+ to F scale,{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/09/victoria-and-abdul-stronger-battle-of-the-sexes-specialty-box-office-1202175803/|title='‘Victoria And Abdul’ Reigns With Top PTA; ‘Stronger’ & ‘Battle Of The Sexes’ Solid – Specialty Box Office|first=Brian|last=Brooks|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=September 24, 2017|accessdate=September 24, 2017}} while [[PostTrak]] reported filmgoers gave the film an overall positive score of 74%. ===Accolades=== {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" |- ! scope="col"| Award ! scope="col"| Date of ceremony ! scope="col"| Category ! scope="col"| Recipient(s) and nominee(s) ! scope="col"| Result ! scope="col" class="unsortable"| {{Abbr|Ref.|Reference}} |- | rowspan="2"| [[AARP|AARP's Movies for Grownups Awards]] | rowspan="2"| February 5, 2018 | Best Actor | [[Steve Carell]] | {{nom}} | rowspan="2" style="text-align:center;"| {{cite web|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/lists/aarps-movies-grownups-awards-2018-post-leads-nominees-1075285/item/ |title=AARP's Movies for Grownups Awards: 'The Post' Leads Nominees |last=Lee |first=Ashley |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date=January 17, 2018|accessdate=January 17, 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.aarp.org/entertainment/movies-for-grownups/info-2018/award-winners-photo.html?intcmp=AE-ENT-M4G-FLXSLDR-SLIDE3|title=Complete List of Winners at the 2018 Movies for Grownups Awards|website=[[AARP]]}}{{cite web|url=https://www.aarp.org/entertainment/movies-for-grownups/info-2018/award-winners-photo.html?intcmp=AE-ENT-M4G-FLXSLDR-SLIDE12|title=Complete List of Winners at the 2018 Movies for Grownups Awards|website=[[AARP]]}} |- | Best Time Capsule | ''Battle of the Sexes'' | {{nom}} |- | [[Casting Society of America]] | January 18, 2018 | Studio or Independent – Comedy | Justine Arteta and Kim Davis-Wagner | {{nom}} | style="text-align:center;"| {{cite web|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/artios-awards-nominees-casting-society-reveals-film-contenders-1071018 |title=Artios Awards: Casting Society Reveals Film Nominees (Exclusive) |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |first=Rebecca |last=Ford |date=January 2, 2018 |accessdate=January 3, 2018}} |- |[[Cinema for Peace|Cinema For Peace Awards]] |February 19, 2018 |Most Valuable Film of the Year |''Battle of the Sexes'' | {{nom}} | style="text-align:center;"|{{Cite web|url=https://www.cinemaforpeace-foundation.org/most-valuable-film-of-the-year/|title=Nominations [[Critics' Choice Movie Award for Best Actor in a Comedy|Best Actor in a Comedy]] | Steve Carell | {{nom}} | rowspan="2" style="text-align:center;"| {{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/12/critics-choice-awards-nominations-the-shape-of-water-dunkirk-this-is-us-netflix-1202220528/|title=Critics’ Choice Awards Nominations: ‘The Shape Of Water’ Leads With 14; Netflix Tops TV Contenders|last=Hammond|first=Pete|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=December 6, 2017|accessdate=December 9, 2017}} |- | [[Critics' Choice Movie Award for Best Actress in a Comedy|Best Actress in a Comedy]] | [[Emma Stone]] | {{nom}} |- | [[Dorian Awards]] | February 24, 2018 | LGBTQ Film of the Year | ''Battle of the Sexes'' | {{nom}} | style="text-align:center;"| |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date=January 10, 2018 |accessdate=January 10, 2018}}
{{cite web|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/dorian-awards-call-me-by-your-name-named-film-year-1080560 |title=Dorian Awards: 'Call Me by Your Name' Hailed as Film of the Year |first=Gregg {{pp-pc1}} {{Use mdy dates|date=June 2015}} {{Infobox venue |stadium_name = Civic Stadium |nickname = |image = Civic Stadium with Aqua Sox - Eugene, Oregon.jpg |image_size = 230 |caption = Emeralds game in July 2004 |location = 2077 Willamette Street,
[[Eugene, Oregon|Eugene]], [[Oregon]], U.S. |coordinates = {{coord|44.037|N|123.091|W|type:landmark_region:US|display=inline,title}} |broke_ground = |opened = {{start date|1938|10|28}}{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=VvRVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=l-EDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6143%2C7283427 |newspaper=Eugene Register-Guard |location=Oregon |last=Shattuck-Smallwood |first=Nancy |title=Civic Stadium puts 50 on the scoreboard |date=August 29, 1989 |page=1E }}
{{Years or months ago|1938}} |closed = {{start date|2009|09|04}} |demolished = |owner = [[Eugene School District]] |operator = |surface = Natural grass |construction_cost = [[United States dollar|$]]18,000 |architect = [[Works Progress Administration]] (WPA) |former_names = |tenants = [[South Eugene High School]]
[[Eugene Emeralds]]
[[Pacific Coast League]] ([[Triple-A (baseball)|AAA]]), 1969–1973
[[Northwest League]] (A), 1974–2009 {{Infobox NRHP | name = Eugene Civic Stadium | embed = yes | nrhp_type = | image = | caption = | location= 2077 Willamette Street,
[[Eugene, Oregon]] | built = 1938, {{Years or months ago|1938}} | architect OR builder = Smith, Graham B.; Bentley, Percy D., et al. | architecture = | added = October 6, 2008 | delisted= March 8, 2016 | governing_body = Local | refnum = 08000183 }} |seating_capacity = 6,800 |dimensions = |pushpin_map = USA Oregon Eugene#USA Oregon }} '''Civic Stadium''' was an outdoor athletic [[stadium]] in the [[Western United States|western]] [[United States]], located in [[Eugene, Oregon|Eugene]], [[Oregon]]. For most of its history it was owned by the [[Eugene School District]]. Opened in 1938,{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=xApWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=TeEDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6628%2C2763673 |newspaper=Eugene Register-Guard |location=Oregon |title=Baseball not new for Civic |last=Harvey |first=Paul, III |date=December 10, 1968 |page=3B }} the stadium was destroyed by fire in 2015 on June 29.{{cite news |title= Eugene's Civic Stadium Goes Up In Flames |date= June 29, 2015 |publisher= [[KGW]]-TV |url= http://www.kgw.com/story/news/2015/06/29/civic-stadium-burns-in-eugene/29493657/ |location=Portland, Oregon |accessdate= June 29, 2015}} ==History== Civic Stadium, located near East 20th Avenue and Willamette Street,{{cite news |first= Jeff |last= Smith |title= Eugene Emeralds Say Hello—And Prepare to Say Goodbye—To Civic Stadium |date= June 19, 2009 |newspaper= [[The Oregonian]] |url= http://www.oregonlive.com/sports/index.ssf/2009/06/eugene_emeralds_say_hello_and.html |accessdate= June 29, 2015}} adjacent to [[South Eugene High School]], had a [[seating capacity]] of 6,800. Built {{Years or months ago|1938}} in 1938 through a public-private partnership between the Eugene Area [[Chamber of Commerce]], Eugene School District 4J, and the federal [[Works Progress Administration]] (WPA);{{cite web |url= http://www.eugene-or.gov%2FDocumentCenter%2FView%2F19613&ei=hy-SVbKVCsfwoASl2J-wDQ&usg=AFQjCNHiIAR__t4Aw-he9bWm51DnibKR4w&sig2=fj2jvRxkm87u1WjFzaeoOA |title= Eugene Modernism 1935-65: Education |date= June 2003}} the property had been owned by the [[Eugene School District|school district]] from its construction until spring 2015.{{cite journal |first = Natalie K. |last= Perrin |title= Eugene Civic Stadium: History, Historic Structures Review, and Preservation Pitch |publisher = University of Oregon, School of Architecture & Allied Arts |date= June 2008 |url= http://www.savecivicstadium.org/files/6614/0968/2792/History4SCS.pdf | accessdate= June 29, 2015}}{{cite news |first= Jes |last= Burns | title= Eugene 4J Looks Once again to Off-load Civic Stadium |date= August 28, 2013 |publisher=[[KLCC (FM)|KLCC]] |url= http://klcc.org/post/eugene-4j-looks-once-again-load-civic-stadium |accessdate= June 29, 2015}} In October 2008, Civic Stadium was added to the [[National Register of Historic Places]].{{cite web |url= http://heritagedata.prd.state.or.us/historic/index.cfm?do=main.loadFile&load=NR_Noms/08000183.pdf |title= National Register of Historic Places Registration Form: Eugene Civic Stadium |publisher= [[National Park Service]] |date= August 27, 2008 |accessdate= June 29, 2015}} Originally built for [[High school football in North America|high school football]] and [[baseball]], in 1969 it became the home of the [[Eugene Emeralds]] [[Minor league baseball|minor league]] baseball team, which previously played at the privately owned Bethel Park (north of Roosevelt Boulevard ({{coordinates|44.0644|-123.1454}}); its outfield is present-day Lark Park).{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=FqtVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=IuEDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5691%2C5849882|newspaper=Eugene Register-Guard |location=Oregon |title=State buys Bethel baseball park |date=October 24, 1969 |page=15A }}{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Y05WAAAAIBAJ&sjid=6esDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4476%2C6918581 |newspaper=Eugene Register-Guard |location=Oregon |last=Clark |first=Bob |title=Deep and playable: Bethel Park |date=June 29, 2004 |page=1D }}{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=yd1WAAAAIBAJ&sjid=pusDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3961%2C141537 |newspaper=Eugene Register-Guard |location=Oregon |title=Civic Stadium |date=August 1, 1999 |page=1D }} The Emeralds moved up to the [[Pacific Coast League]] ([[Triple-A (baseball)|AAA]]) in 1969 and needed a larger venue. After five seasons in the PCL, they returned to the Class A [[Northwest League]] in 1974 and played in the stadium through 2009.{{cite web |url= http://web.minorleaguebaseball.com/team4/page.jsp?ymd=20100510&content_id=9949000&vkey=team4_t461&fext=.jsp&sid=t461 |title= Eugene Emeralds: History |accessdate= June 29, 2015}} (High school football moved to the [[Oregon Ducks football|University of Oregon's]] [[Autzen Stadium]] in 1969, following the installation of [[artificial turf]].) Before the departure of the Emeralds in 2009, Civic Stadium was one of the ten oldest active minor league baseball facilities in the United States.{{cite news |first= Edward |last= Russo |title= Civic Engineering: The Future of Eugene's Historic Stadium is at Issue — Again |date= August 19, 2013 |newspaper= [[The Register-Guard]]}} The lighted playing field at Civic Stadium had an unorthodox alignment, oriented southeast (home plate to center field); the recommended alignment of a baseball diamond is east-northeast.{{cite web |url=http://mlb.mlb.com/mlb/downloads/y2008/official_rules/01_objectives_of_the_game.pdf |publisher=Major League Baseball |title=Playing Field Orientation – Rule 1.04 |accessdate=June 29, 2015}} ==Emeralds relocate== In August 2009, the Emeralds announced their relocation to the [[University of Oregon]]'s [[PK Park]] for the 2010 season. The Emeralds cited Civic Stadium's need of substantial renovations, major problems with irrigation and electrical systems, as well as broken seats, and estimated that modernization could cost as much as $15 million.{{cite news |first= Benjamin |last= Hill |title= Emeralds Pick PK for New Home |date= August 25, 2009 |publisher=Eugene Emeralds |url= http://eugene.emeralds.milb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20090825&content_id=6610654&vkey=news_milb&fext=.jsp |accessdate= June 15, 2015}} The Emeralds played their last game at Civic Stadium on Thursday, September 4, 2009, a 5-3 loss to the [[Salem-Keizer Volcanoes]]. Following the game, fans collected pieces of the outfield turf as souvenirs.{{cite news |first= Dan |last= Morrison |title= Ems Play Final Game at Civic Stadium |date= September 4, 2009 |publisher= [[KVAL-TV|KVAL]] |url= http://www.kval.com/news/local/57318612.html |accessdate= June 29, 2015}} ==Disuse and destruction== By 2009, the school district designated the stadium a surplus property, although the district had not made a decision on whether to sell it.{{cite news |first= Arrianee |last= LeBeau |title= What Does the Future Hold for Civic Stadium? |date= September 2, 2009 |publisher= [[KVAL-TV|KVAL]] |url= http://www.kval.com/news/local/56839787.html |accessdate= June 29, 2015}} As recently as 2007, the school district examined options to redevelop all or part of the property, most likely as medium-density residential units.{{citation |publisher= School District 4J |title= Board of Directors Meeting Minutes |accessdate= June 29, 2015 |date= December 12, 2007 |url= http://www.4j.lane.edu/files/board/reports/4J_BOD_report_2007-12-12.pdf}} A local group, Friends of Civic Stadium, started a [[grassroots]] campaign in support of restoring the historic venue while also attempting to find alternative tenants.{{cite web |url= http://www.savecivicstadium.org |title=Save Civic Stadium}} With the future of the stadium in flux, it was one of ten entries on [[Restore Oregon]]'s [[Oregon's Most Endangered Places|Most Endangered Places in Oregon]] 2011 list.{{cite web|url=http://www.historicpreservationleague.org/mep_CivicStadium.php |title=Most Endangered Places 2011: Civic Stadium |publisher=[[Restore Oregon]] |accessdate=June 5, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111110165432/http://www.historicpreservationleague.org/mep_CivicStadium.php |archivedate=November 10, 2011 }} In April 2015, the Eugene Civic Alliance raised $4.1 million to buy the stadium and 10 acres of surrounding property from the school district.{{cite web |url= http://registerguard.com/rg/news/local/32930735-75/kidsports-key-in-saving-eugenes-civic-stadium.html.csp |last= Russo |first= Edward |title= Civic Lesson in Eugene |newspaper = The Register-Guard |date= April 5, 2015 |accessdate= June 29, 2015}} Eugene Civic Alliance is a non-profit made up of community leaders, including [[Lane United FC]] managing director Dave Galas, and the executive director of the Eugene youth sports organization Kidsports, former Ducks basketball player [[Bev Smith]].{{cite web |url= http://www.laneunitedfc.com/blog/2015/3/civic-stadium |title= Civic Stadium: A Community Triumph of the Past, Present and future |publisher= Lane United FC |date= March 3, 2015 |accessdate= June 29, 2015}} On June 29, 2015, Civic Stadium was destroyed by fire.{{cite web |url= http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/historic-eugene-oregon-stadium-engulfed-flames-n384156 |title= Historic Civic Stadium in Eugene, Oregon Engulfed in Flames |publisher= NBC News |accessdate= June 29, 2015}} Two days later, officials charged four pre-teen boys in connection with the fire, although the cause had not yet been determined conclusively.{{cite web |url= http://www.katu.com/news/local/4-children-to-faces-charges-in-Civic-Stadium-fire-311341641.html |title= 4 Children to Face Charges in Civic Stadium Fire |publisher= [[KATU]] |accessdate= July 1, 2015}} The stadium was delisted from the National Register of Historic Places on March 8, 2016.{{cite web | publisher = National Park Service | title = Weekly List of Actions Taken on Properties: 3/07/16 through 3/11/16 | date = March 18, 2016 | url = http://www.nps.gov/nr/listings/20160318.htm | deadurl = no | accessdate = March 22, 2016 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160322030827/http://www.nps.gov/nr/listings/20160318.htm | archivedate = March 22, 2016}} File:Civic Stadium Fire Eugene Oregon.jpg|The stadium on fire File:Civic Stadium Grandstand After June 2015 Fire.JPG|Grandstand, shortly after the fire File:Civic Stadium Fire-1.jpg|Field, July 2015 File:Civic Stadium Fire-5.jpg|Former grandstand and field, July 2015 File:Ruins of <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Logo of the FCC.jpg|thumb|FCC logo]] -->
The '''Costa Rican Cycling Federation''' or '''FECOCI''' (in [[Spanish language|Spanish]]: ''Federación Costarricense de Ciclismo'') is the national [[sport governing body|governing body]] of [[bicycle racing|cycle racing]] in [[Costa Rica]]. [[Hernán Solano]] was elected President of the federation in 2011 and again in 2013.

The FECOCI is a member of the [[Union Cycliste Internationale|UCI]] and [[Confederacion Panamericana de Ciclismo|COPACI]].

==External links==
* {{Official website|http://www.fecoci.net/}}

revision.text:
[[Physical exercise]] has been found to be associated with changes in [[androgen]] levels. In cross-sectional analyses, aerobic exercisers have lower basal total and free testosterone compared to the sedentary.<ref name="arce">{{cite journal |vauthors=Arce JC, De Souza MJ, Pescatello LS, Luciano AA | title = Subclinical alterations in hormone and semen profile in athletes | journal = Fertility and Sterility | volume = 59 | issue = 2 | pages = 398–404 | year = 1993 | pmid = 8425638 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Hackney AC, Sinning WE, Bruot BC | title = Reproductive hormonal profiles of endurance-trained and untrained males | journal = Medicine & Science in Sports & Exercise | volume = 20 | issue = 1 | pages = 60–65 | year = 1988 | pmid = 3343919 | doi = 10.1249/00005768-198802000-00009 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Wheeler GD, Wall SR, Belcastro AN, Cumming DC | title = Reduced serum testosterone and prolactin levels in male distance runners | journal = JAMA: The Journal of the American Medical Association | volume = 252 | issue = 4 | pages = 514–516 | year = 1984 | pmid = 6429357 | doi = 10.1001/jama.252.4.514 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Cooper CS, Taaffe DR, Guido D, Packer E, Holloway L, Marcus R | title = Relationship of chronic endurance exercise to the somatotropic and sex hormone status of older men | journal = [[European Journal of Endocrinology]] / European Federation of Endocrine Societies |publisher=[[Bioscientifica]]| volume = 138 | issue = 5 | pages = 517–523 | year = 1998 | pmid = 9625362 | doi=10.1530/eje.0.1380517}}</ref> [[Anaerobic exercise]]rs also have lower testosterone compared to the sedentary<ref name="arce"/> but a slight increase in basal testosterone with resistance training over time.<ref name="2 year"/> There is some correlation between testosterone and physical activity in the middle aged and elderly.<ref name="nordic">{{cite journal |vauthors=Muller M, den Tonkelaar I, Thijssen JH, Grobbee DE, van der Schouw YT | title = Endogenous sex hormones in men aged 40-80 years | journal = European Journal of Endocrinology / European Federation of Endocrine Societies | volume = 149 | issue = 6 | pages = 583–589 | year = 2003 | pmid = 14641001 | doi = 10.1530/eje.0.1490583 }}</ref> Acutely, testosterone briefly increases when comparing aerobic, anaerobic and mixed forms of exercise.<ref name="Kramer">{{cite journal |vauthors=Kraemer WJ, Häkkinen K, Newton RU, McCormick M, Nindl BC, Volek JS, Gotshalk LA, Fleck SJ, Campbell WW, Gordon SE, Farrell PA, Evans WJ | title = Acute hormonal responses to heavy resistance exercise in younger and older men | journal = European journal of applied physiology and occupational physiology | volume = 77 | issue = 3 | pages = 206–211 | year = 1998 | pmid = 9535580 | doi = 10.1007/s004210050323 }}</ref> A study assessed men who were resistance trained, endurance trained, or sedentary in which they either rested, ran or did a resistance session. Androgens increased in response to exercise, particularly resistance, while cortisol only increased with resistance. DHEA increased with resistance exercise and remained elevated during recovery in resistance-trained subjects. After initial post-exercise increase, there was decline in free and total testosterone during resistance recovery, particularly in resistance-trained subjects. Endurance-trained subjects showed less change in hormone levels in response to exercise than resistance-trained subjects.<ref name="combined">{{cite journal |vauthors=Tremblay MS, Copeland JL, Van Helder W | title = Effect of training status and exercise mode on endogenous steroid hormones in men | journal = Journal of Applied Physiology | volume = 96 | issue = 2 | pages = 531–539 | year = 2004 | pmid = 14514704 | pmc = | doi = 10.1152/japplphysiol.00656.2003 }}</ref> Another study found relative short term effects of aerobic, anaerobic and combined anaerobic-aerobic exercise protocols on hormone levels did not change. The study noted increases in testosterone and cortisol immediately after exercise, which in 2 hours returned to baseline levels.<ref name="arbcvsanrbc">{{cite journal |vauthors=Hackney AC, Premo MC, McMurray RG | title = Influence of aerobic versus anaerobic exercise on the relationship between reproductive hormones in men | journal = Journal of Sports Sciences | volume = 13 | issue = 4 | pages = 305–311 | year = 1995 | pmid = 7474044 | pmc = | doi = 10.1080/02640419508732244 }}</ref>
==Aerobic== In trained long term aerobic exercisers, basal levels are unchanged,<ref name="longtermaerobic">{{cite journal |vauthors=Fellmann N, Coudert J, Jarrige JF, Bedu M, Denis C, Boucher D, Lacour JR | title = Effects of Endurance Training on the Androgenic Response to Exercise in Man | journal = International Journal of Sports Medicine | volume = 6| issue = 4 | pages = 215–219 | year = 2008 | pmid = 4044106 | pmc = | doi = 10.1055/s-2008-1025843 }}</ref> or decreased.<ref name="arbcvsanrbc"/><ref name="longtermaerobic2">{{cite journal |vauthors=Hackney AC, Fahrner CL, Gulledge TP | title = Basal reproductive hormonal profiles are altered in endurance trained men | journal = The Journal of sports medicine and physical fitness | volume = 38 | issue = 2 | pages = 138–141 | year = 1998 | pmid = 9763799 }}</ref> Acutely, endurance based aerobic efforts cause testosterone to rise.<ref name="jensen">{{cite journal |vauthors=Jensen J, Oftebro H, Breigan B, Johnsson A, Ohlin K, Meen HD, Strømme SB, Dahl HA | title = Comparison of changes in testosterone concentrations after strength and endurance exercise in well trained men | journal = European journal of applied physiology and occupational physiology | volume = 63 | issue = 6 | pages = 467–471 | year = 1991 | pmid = 1765061 | doi = 10.1007/bf00868080 }}</ref>
A year long, moderate-intensity aerobic exercise program increased DHT and SHBG in sedentary men age 40–75, but had no effect on other androgens. Both DHT and SHBG increased 14% in exercisers at 3 months, and at 12 months they remained 9% above baseline. SHBG is protective against DHT as it binds free androgen.<ref name="Hawkins">{{cite journal |vauthors=Hawkins VN, Foster-Schubert K, Chubak J, Sorensen B, Ulrich CM, Stancyzk FZ, Plymate S, Stanford J, White E, Potter JD, McTiernan A | title = Effect of Exercise on Serum Sex Hormones in Men | journal = Medicine & Science in Sports & Exercise | volume = 40 | issue = 2 | pages = 223–233 | year = 2008 | pmid = 18202581 | pmc = 3040039 | doi = 10.1249/mss.0b013e31815bbba9 }}</ref> In acute assessment of hormone levels in soccer players before, during and after a game, DHT and testosterone increased during the match, but returned to baseline after 45 minutes rest.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Lupo C, Baldi L, Bonifazi M, Lodi L, Martelli G, Viti A, Carli G | title = Androgen levels following a football match | journal = European journal of applied physiology and occupational physiology | volume = 54 | issue = 5 | pages = 494–496 | year = 1985 | pmid = 4085477 | doi = 10.1007/bf00422958 }}</ref> Aerobic exercise in Japanese rats done on a rodent treadmill doubled local concentrations of DHT in calf muscles as assessed by protein assay.<ref name="fatrats">{{cite journal |vauthors=Sato K, Iemitsu M, Aizawa K, Mesaki N, Ajisaka R, Fujita S | title = DHEA administration and exercise training improves insulin resistance in obese rats | journal = Nutrition & Metabolism | volume = 9 | pages = 47 | year = 2012 | pmid = 22647230 | pmc = 3433349 | doi = 10.1186/1743-7075-9-47 }}</ref> After intense aerobic effort, high endurance athletes were also found to have lower free testosterone the next day.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Daly W, Seegers CA, Rubin DA, Dobridge JD, Hackney AC | title = Relationship between stress hormones and testosterone with prolonged endurance exercise | journal = European Journal of Applied Physiology | volume = 93 | issue = 4 | pages = 375–380 | year = 2004 | pmid = 15618989 | pmc = | doi = 10.1007/s00421-004-1223-1 }}</ref> In prolonged endurance exercise, such as a marathon, levels ultimately decrease.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Dressendorfer RH, Wade CE | title = Effects of a 15-d race on plasma steroid levels and leg muscle fitness in runners | journal = Medicine & Science in Sports & Exercise | volume = 23 | issue = 8 | pages = 954–958 | year = 1991 | pmid = 1956271 | doi=10.1249/00005768-199108000-00012}}</ref> Similarly, DHT drops, while adrenal androgen and cortisol will increase with the stress response.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Morville R, Pesquies PC, Guezennec CY, Serrurier BD, Guignard M | title = Plasma variations in testicular and adrenal androgens during prolonged physical exercise in man | journal = Annales d'endocrinologie | volume = 40 | issue = 5 | pages = 501–510 | year = 1979 | pmid = 518032 }}</ref>
==Anaerobic== [[File:TwoDumbbells.JPG|thumb|right|Effects of anaerobic exercise also vary with length of time.]] It is unknown if anaerobic training changes individual hormone profiles, or if conditioned athletes in studies self-selected because of physiologic predisposition to athletic conditioning.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Bunt JC | title = Hormonal alterations due to exercise | journal = Sports Medicine | volume = 3 | issue = 5 | pages = 331–345 | year = 1986 | pmid = 3529282 | doi = 10.2165/00007256-198603050-00003 }}</ref> There is variation of response to anaerobic stress depending on exercise intensity, age, gender, length of time studied, and time at which serum indices were drawn. Most studies report that testosterone increases or is unchanged acutely, though some even report it to decrease. Anaerobic exercisers have testosterone levels below sedentary controls in cross sectional analysis. Over months to years, levels are stable to slightly increased.
The [[Testosterone-cortisol ratio|ratio of testosterone to cortisol]] can both increase<ref name="Scand2"/> and decrease<ref name="Scand1"/> during resistance training, depending on intensity of exercise. A study comparing young and old subjects showed acute ''increases'' in GH and testosterone for both, although the latter increased less in older men.<ref name="Hakk98">{{cite journal |vauthors=Häkkinen K, Pakarinen A, Newton RU, Kraemer WJ | title = Acute hormone responses to heavy resistance lower and upper extremity exercise in young versus old men | journal = European journal of applied physiology and occupational physiology | volume = 77 | issue = 4 | pages = 312–319 | year = 1998 | pmid = 9562359 | doi = 10.1007/s004210050339 }}</ref> Testosterone rises in late hours of sleep after anaerobic exercise.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=McMurray RG, Eubank TK, Hackney AC | title = Nocturnal hormonal responses to resistance exercise | journal = European journal of applied physiology and occupational physiology | volume = 72 | issue = 1–2 | pages = 121–126 | year = 1995 | pmid = 8789582 | doi = 10.1007/bf00964126 }}</ref> Androgen receptor expression increases with acute exercise in correlation to free testosterone.<ref name="Willow">{{cite journal |vauthors=Willoughby DS, Taylor L | title = Effects of sequential bouts of resistance exercise on androgen receptor expression | journal = Medicine & Science in Sports & Exercise | volume = 36 | issue = 9 | pages = 1499–1506 | year = 2004 | pmid = 15354030 | doi = 10.1249/01.mss.0000139795.83030.d1 }}</ref> When comparing men and women in the 30, 50 and 70 year age groups, young and middle aged men showed increased testosterone after exercise, with the latter also having increased cortisol. Elderly men showed no change.<ref name="Hakk age">{{cite journal |vauthors=Häkkinen K, Pakarinen A | title = Acute Hormonal Responses to Heavy Resistance Exercise in Men and Women at Different Ages | journal = International Journal of Sports Medicine | volume = 16 | issue = 8 | pages = 507–513 | year = 2007 | pmid = 8776203 | pmc = | doi = 10.1055/s-2007-973045 }}</ref> Other studies have also shown with age there is a downtrend of testosterone<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Baker JR, Bemben MG, Anderson MA, Bemben DA | title = Effects of Age on Testosterone Responses to Resistance Exercise and Musculoskeletal Variables in Men | journal = The Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research | volume = 20 | issue = 4 | pages = 874–881 | year = 2006 | pmid = 17194250 | pmc = | doi = 10.1519/R-18885.1 }}</ref> and attenuated growth hormone response.<ref name="smilios">{{cite journal |vauthors=Smilios I, Pilianidis T, Karamouzis M, Parlavantzas A, Tokmakidis SP | title = Hormonal Responses after a Strength Endurance Resistance Exercise Protocol in Young and Elderly Males | journal = International Journal of Sports Medicine | volume = 28 | issue = 5 | pages = 401–406 | year = 2007 | pmid = 17024619 | pmc = | doi = 10.1055/s-2006-924366 }}</ref> Young men have shown ''no acute change'' in testosterone with resistance training, with increase in cortisol and growth hormone depending on intensity.<ref name="Smil2"/> One study in young men showed testosterone acutely stable, with increase in GH and IGF-1.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Pullinen T, Mero A, Huttunen P, Pakarinen A, Komi PV | title = Resistance exercise-induced hormonal responses in men, women, and pubescent boys | journal = Medicine & Science in Sports & Exercise | volume = 34 | issue = 5 | pages = 806–813 | year = 2002 | pmid = 11984299 | doi = 10.1097/00005768-200205000-00013 }}</ref> Similarly, a study showed testosterone did not increase in young men, women, and pubescent boys unaccustomed to weight training when corrected for plasma volume.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Kraemer RR, Kilgore JL, Kraemer GR, Castracane VD | title = Growth hormone, IGF-I, and testosterone responses to resistive exercise | journal = Medicine & Science in Sports & Exercise | volume = 24 | issue = 12 | pages = 1346–1352 | year = 1992 | pmid = 1470017 | doi=10.1249/00005768-199212000-00007}}</ref> Extreme intensity of [[strength training]] may trigger the stress response, resulting in lower testosterone levels,<ref name="Raas">{{cite journal |vauthors=Raastad T, Glomsheller T, Bjøro T, Hallén J | title = Changes in human skeletal muscle contractility and hormone status during 2 weeks of heavy strength training | journal = European Journal of Applied Physiology | volume = 84 | issue = 1–2 | pages = 54–63 | year = 2001 | pmid = 11394254 | pmc = | doi = 10.1007/s004210000328 }}</ref> an effect accentuated by energy deprivation.<ref name="Berg">{{cite journal |vauthors=Bergendahl M, Aloi JA, Iranmanesh A, Mulligan TM, Veldhuis JD | title = Fasting suppresses pulsatile luteinizing hormone (LH) secretion and enhances orderliness of LH release in young but not older men | journal = The Journal of Clinical Endocrinology and Metabolism | volume = 83 | issue = 6 | pages = 1967–1975 | year = 1998 | pmid = 9626127 | doi = 10.1210/jc.83.6.1967 }}</ref> A separate study comparing different ages, however, found no difference in acute testosterone and cortisol levels between groups, but attenuated [[growth hormone]] response in the elderly.<ref name="smilios"/> Acutely, other studies have shown testosterone to increase.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Kraemer WJ, Marchitelli L, Gordon SE, Harman E, Dziados JE, Mello R, Frykman P, McCurry D, Fleck SJ | title = Hormonal and growth factor responses to heavy resistance exercise protocols | journal = Journal of Applied Physiology | volume = 69 | issue = 4 | pages = 1442–1450 | year = 1990 | pmid = 2262468 }}</ref> In a small group of anaerobically trained athletes, stressful training acutely even ''decreased'' serum testosterone and its ratio to [[cortisol]] and [[Sex hormone binding globulin|SHBG]], with an increase in [[Luteinizing hormone|LH]]. With subsequent decompensation, testosterone was stable, but cortisol and SHBG decreased.<ref name="Scand1">{{cite journal |vauthors=Häkkinen K, Pakarinen A, Alén M, Kauhanen H, Komi PV | title = Relationships between training volume, physical performance capacity, and serum hormone concentrations during prolonged training in elite weight lifters | journal = International journal of sports medicine | volume = 8 Suppl 1 | pages = 61–65 | year = 1987 | pmid = 3108174 }}</ref> Another case control showed with intense training followed by rest, testosterone dropped and LH increased initially.<ref name="Scand4">{{cite journal |vauthors=Busso T, Häkkinen K, Pakarinen A, Kauhanen H, Komi PV, Lacour JR | title = Hormonal adaptations and modelled responses in elite weightlifters during 6 weeks of training | journal = European journal of applied physiology and occupational physiology | volume = 64 | issue = 4 | pages = 381–386 | year = 1992 | pmid = 1592066 | doi = 10.1007/bf00636228 }}</ref>
Interval and quality of exercise also affect hormonal response. Sessions of moderate to high intensity with multiple sets and short time intervals, during which energy is derived from glycolytic lactate metabolism, appear to be the greatest stimulus for steroid hormone response. Hormonal response in young men varies with the number of sets in the exercise session. However, when the number increased from 4 to 6, anabolic levels stabilized and cortisol continued to rise, suggesting that alterations in anaerobic volume could alter anabolic and catabolic hormonal balance.<ref name="Smil2">{{cite journal |vauthors=Smilios I, Pilianidis T, Karamouzis M, Tokmakidis SP | title = Hormonal Responses after Various Resistance Exercise Protocols | journal = Medicine & Science in Sports & Exercise | volume = 35 | issue = 4 | pages = 644–654 | year = 2003 | pmid = 12673149 | pmc = | doi = 10.1249/01.MSS.0000058366.04460.5F }}</ref> When sets are performed at maximum repetitions, interval has no influence at a certain intensity range, with no acute hormone response difference between protocols at 10 maximum reps with 2- and 5-minute intervals.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Ahtiainen JP, Pakarinen A, Alen M, Kraemer WJ, Häkkinen K | title = Short vs. Long Rest Period Between the Sets in Hypertrophic Resistance Training: Influence on Muscle Strength, Size, and Hormonal Adaptations in Trained Men | journal = The Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research | volume = 19 | issue = 3 | pages = 572–582 | year = 2005 | pmid = 16095405 | pmc = | doi = 10.1519/15604.1 }}</ref> There is a higher total testosterone response in hypertrophy protocols compared to those for strength and power, despite equalization of total work load (defined as load x sets x repetitions).<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=McCaulley GO, McBride JM, Cormie P, Hudson MB, Nuzzo JL, Quindry JC, Travis Triplett N | title = Acute hormonal and neuromuscular responses to hypertrophy, strength and power type resistance exercise | journal = European Journal of Applied Physiology | volume = 105 | issue = 5 | pages = 695–704 | year = 2008 | pmid = 19066934 | pmc = | doi = 10.1007/s00421-008-0951-z }}</ref> There is a 27% greater testosterone response using protocols with simultaneous use of all four limbs. Androgenic response was also noted in protocols using upper and lower limbs separately to a lesser degree.<ref name="Hakk98"/>
A number of studies have looked at effects of anaerobic exercise over months to years, showing it to be constant or slightly increased. A small case-control of anaerobic training in young untrained males over six weeks found decline in free testosterone of 17 percent.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Ara I, Perez-Gomez J, Vicente-Rodriguez G, Chavarren J, Dorado C, Calbet JA | title = Serum free testosterone, leptin and soluble leptin receptor changes in a 6-week strength-training programme | journal = The British Journal of Nutrition | volume = 96 | issue = 6 | pages = 1053–1059 | year = 2006 | pmid = 17181880 | doi = 10.1017/bjn20061956 }}</ref> With men in their 60s, resistive training over 16 weeks did not affect baseline anabolic hormone levels, although GH increased acutely with exercise.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Nicklas BJ, Ryan AJ, Treuth MM, Harman SM, Blackman MR, Hurley BF, Rogers MA | title = Testosterone, Growth Hormone and IGF-I Responses to Acute and Chronic Resistive Exercise in Men Aged 55-70 Years | journal = International Journal of Sports Medicine | volume = 16 | issue = 7 | pages = 445–450 | year = 2007 | pmid = 8550252 | pmc = | doi = 10.1055/s-2007-973035 }}</ref> A study over 21 weeks in male strength athletes showed basal hormone levels to be constant, despite strength increase.<ref name="Aht">{{cite journal |vauthors=Ahtiainen JP, Pakarinen A, Alen M, Kraemer WJ, Häkkinen K | title = Muscle hypertrophy, hormonal adaptations and strength development during strength training in strength-trained and untrained men | journal = European Journal of Applied Physiology | volume = 89 | issue = 6 | pages = 555–563 | year = 2003 | pmid = 12734759 | pmc = | doi = 10.1007/s00421-003-0833-3 }}</ref> A follow up study looked at a larger group of weight trainers over 24 weeks, with 12-week decompensation. Training caused no change in total testosterone, but there were decreases in free testosterone, [[progesterone]], [[androstendione]], [[DHEA]], cortisol, [[transcortin]], and in the [[Cortisol binding globulin|cortisol:CBG]] ratio, suggesting androgen turnover increased with training intensity, without change in total testosterone.<ref name="Scand2">{{cite journal |vauthors=Alén M, Pakarinen A, Häkkinen K, Komi PV | title = Responses of serum androgenic-anabolic and catabolic hormones to prolonged strength training | journal = International journal of sports medicine | volume = 9 | issue = 3 | pages = 229–233 | year = 1988 | pmid = 3410630 | doi=10.1055/s-2007-1025011}}</ref> A study looking at young men and resistance training over 48 weeks found increases in baseline serum testosterone from 20 ± 5 to 25 ± 5 nmol/l, and an increase in testosterone:SHBG ratio, LH and FSH.<ref name="2 year">{{cite journal |vauthors=Häkkinen K, Pakarinen A, Alen M, Kauhanen H, Komi PV | title = Neuromuscular and hormonal adaptations in athletes to strength training in two years | journal = Journal of Applied Physiology | volume = 65 | issue = 6 | pages = 2406–2412 | year = 1988 | pmid = 3215840 }}</ref>
==Combined training== One study showed [[Growth hormone|GH]] increase with anaerobic effort to be blunted in those who performed aerobic training for 60 minutes prior to strength training. Testosterone levels remained high only at the end of the training session with aerobic training followed by strength training, a phenomenon not seen with weight training done before aerobics.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Goto K, Higashiyama M, Ishii N, Takamatsu K | title = Prior endurance exercise attenuates growth hormone response to subsequent resistance exercise | journal = European Journal of Applied Physiology | volume = 94 | issue = 3 | pages = 333–338 | year = 2005 | pmid = 15714290 | pmc = | doi = 10.1007/s00421-004-1296-x }}</ref> In an 11-week soccer training program focusing on combined vertical jumps, short sprints, and submaximal endurance running, total testosterone increased, but SHBG rose in parallel, maintaining a constant free androgen index.<ref name="Soccer">{{cite journal |vauthors=Gorostiaga EM, Izquierdo M, Ruesta M, Iribarren J, González-Badillo JJ, Ibáñez J | title = Strength training effects on physical performance and serum hormones in young soccer players | journal = European Journal of Applied Physiology | volume = 91 | issue = 5–6 | pages = 698–707 | year = 2003 | pmid = 14704801 | pmc = | doi = 10.1007/s00421-003-1032-y }}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
[[Category:Physical exercise]] [[Category:Testosterone]]

revision.text:
'''Footballer's Ankle''' is a pinching or impingement of the ligaments or tendons of the ankle between the bones, particularly the [[talus bone|talus]] and [[tibia]]. This results in pain, inflammation and swelling. == Causes == A common cause of anterior impingement is a bone spur on anklebone ([[talus bone|talus]]) or the shinbone ([[tibia]]). Repeated kicking actions can cause the anklebone to hit the bottom of the shinbone, which can lead to a lump of bone (or [[bone spur]]) developing. This bone spur may then begin to impact on the soft tissue at the front of the ankle, causing [[inflammation]] and swelling. The condition is most common in athletes who repeatedly bend the ankle upward ([[dorsiflexion]]), such as footballers, hence the name. == Symptoms == - pain and tenderness over anterior ankle joint
- pain on dorsiflexion and plantar flexion
- band of pain across anterior ankle when kicking a ball
- palpable bony lump on distal tibia or superior talus == Treatment == - [[soft tissue technique]]s to stretch muscles crossing the ankle to relieve tension
- mobilisation of ankle joint
- steroid injection to reduce inflammation
- surgery to remove bony spurs ==External links== *[http://nottingham-massage.blogspot.com/2009/03/footballers-ankle.html] What is Footballer's Ankle? *[http://www.simonmoyes.com/trt_ankle_football.php] Simon Moyes: Anterior Impingement (Footballer's Ankle) [[Category:Sports injuries]] [[Category:Association football culture]] [[Category:Australian rules football culture]] [[Category:Gaelic games culture]] [[Category:Rugby football culture]]

{{Infobox horseraces | surface = Turf | class = Group One | horse race = Hong Kong Derby | image = [[File:2009 Hong Kong Derby.JPG|260px]] | caption = The start of the 2009 Hong Kong Derby | location = [[Sha Tin Racecourse]]
[[Hong Kong]] | inaugurated = 1873 | race type = Thoroughbred | website = [http://www.hongkongderby.com/ Hong Kong Derby] | distance = 2000m (10 furlongs) | track = Right-handed | qualification = Four-years-old only | weight = [[Colt (horse)|Colt]]/[[Gelding]]: [[Pound (mass)|126 lbs]] (57.2 kg)
[[Filly]]: 122 lbs. (55.3 kg) | purse = HK$18 million | bonuses = }} The '''Hong Kong Derby''' is a [[Hong Kong]] [[Thoroughbred horse race]] held annually since 1873. Restricted to horses four-years-old only since 1981, the race is run in mid-March and is the premier event on the domestic racing programme with a purse of HK$18 million (app. US$2.3 million). The first Hong Kong Derby was raced at [[Happy Valley Racecourse]] but in 1979 was transferred permanently to its present location at [[Sha Tin Racecourse]]. Since 1981, the Derby has been won by several horses who went on to earn [[Hong Kong Horse of the Year]] honors including Football, Co-Tack, Yuno When and River Verdon. In 2003, Elegant Fashion became the first filly to win the Derby since 1976. From 2004 to 2012, the race was sponsored by [[Mercedes-Benz]]. It is sponsored by BMW since 2013. ==Race distance== The racing distance of the Hong Kong Derby has varied over the years. From 2000 to present, the distance has been 2000 metres, with the starting point in front of the Sha Tin grandstand. From 1977 to 1999, the race was held over 1800m. From 1973 to 1976, the distance was 2230m. From 1967 to 1972, the distance was "From The Two Mile Post Once Round & In" (1 mile 171 yards.) From 1963 to 1966, the distance was 1 1/4 mile. In 1961 & 1962, the distance was "From the Half Mile Post Once Round & In" (1 mile 3 furlongs 65 yards.) From 1947 to 1960, the distance was 1 1/2 mile. ==Past winners== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size:90%" |- ! style="width:36px" | Year
