70,138 (2013)
72,500 (1987–2011)
58,000 (1968–1986)
55,000 (1950–1967)
40,000 (1936–1949)
30,000 (1920–1935) }} {{Location map |USA |relief = 1 |label = Seattle |lat = 47.65 |long = -122.302 |caption = Location in the [[United States]] |float = |marksize = 5 |background = |width = 240 }} ''' Alaska Airlines Field at Husky Stadium''' (colloquially known as simply '''Husky Stadium''') is an outdoor [[American football|football]] [[stadium]] in the [[Pacific Northwest|northwest]] [[United States]], located on the campus of the [[University of Washington]] in [[Seattle]], [[Washington (state)|Washington]]. It has been the home of the [[Washington Huskies]] of the [[Pac-12 Conference]] since 1920, hosting its [[Washington Huskies football|football]] games. The university also holds its annual commencement at the stadium in June. It is located at the southeastern corner of campus, between Montlake Boulevard N.E. and [[Union Bay (Seattle)|Union Bay]], just north of the [[Montlake Cut]]. The stadium is served by the [[University of Washington station|University of Washington]] [[Link light rail]] station, as well as several bus routes. The stadium underwent a $280 million renovation that was completed in [[2013 Washington Huskies football team|2013]]. Its U-shaped design was specifically oriented (18.167° south of due east) to minimize glare from the early afternoon sun in the athletes' eyes.[http://gohuskies.cstv.com/facilities/husky-stadium.html University of Washington – Official Athletic Site: Facilities] The stadium's open end overlooks scenic [[Lake Washington]] and the [[Cascade Range|Cascade Mountains]], including [[Mount Rainier]]. Prior to the 2013 renovation, its total capacity of 72,500 made it the largest stadium in the [[Pacific Northwest]] and [[List of NCAA Division I FBS football stadiums|one of the largest]] stadiums in college football. ==History== The original stadium was built {{Time ago|1920}} in 1920{{cite news|last=Condotta|first=Bob|title=Will tickets to new Husky Stadium cost a lot more?|url=http://seattletimes.com/html/huskies/2015876084_uwfb11.html|newspaper=The Seattle Times|date=August 10, 2011}} by [[Puget Sound Bridge and Dredging Company]] with a [[seating capacity]] of 30,000. It replaced [[Denny Field (Washington)|Denny Field]], located at the north end of campus, south of NE 45th St. and 20th Ave NE. Husky Stadium's first game was the concluding game of the [[1920 Washington Sun Dodgers football team|1920]] season, a 28–7 loss to [[1920 Dartmouth Indians football team|Dartmouth]] on November 27. In the summer of 1923, the stadium was the site of [[President of the United States|President]] [[Warren Harding]]'s final public address on July 27,{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=WFxXAAAAIBAJ&sjid=_u8DAAAAIBAJ&pg=6860%2C4930474 |work=Eugene Daily Guard |location=(Oregon) |agency=United Press |title=President is set against exploitation |last=Martin |first=Lawrence |date=July 28, 1923 |page=1}} less than a week before his unexpected death in [[San Francisco]]. The capacity of the lower bowl was expanded with the addition of 10,000 seats around the rim in 1936, and a few thousand more in 1968. The first of the stadium's iconic covered grandstands was constructed in [[1950 Washington Huskies football team|1950]], adding 15,000 seats to the south side.{{cite news |title=Seattle History: The first time Husky Stadium came down |url=http://blog.seattlepi.com/thebigblog/2011/12/22/seattle-history-the-first-time-husky-stadium-came-down/#2238-1|newspaper=[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]|date=December 22, 2011 |accessdate=November 12, 2012}} [[File:Aerial Husky Stadium November 2011 - 1.jpg|thumb|left|An aerial view of Husky Stadium as seen the day before the start of the 2011 renovation project.
"Go Huskies" and the "W" logo were painted on the
north and south decks in September 2008.[http://www.gohuskies.com/sports/m-footbl/recaps/090608aal.html Washington-BYU Postgame Notes] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120222040534/http://www.gohuskies.com/sports/m-footbl/recaps/090608aal.html |date=2012-02-22 }}]] In [[1987 Washington Huskies football team|1987]], 13,000 seats were added with the construction of the north grandstand.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=kGpfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=3S4MAAAAIBAJ&pg=4061%2C1449046|newspaper=[[Lewiston Morning Tribune]]|agency=Associated Press|title=UW Regents Approve Plans for Husky Stadium Addition|date=April 20, 1985|page=2C}} Similar to the south stand, this structure included a cantilevered steel roof covering a portion of the lower seats. The project made headlines on February 25, 1987, when the grandstand collapsed during construction as a result of miscommunication between the workers and the contractor, which lead to the premature removal during the intended replacement of several support cables.{{cite web|last1=Manno|first1=Dominic|title=University of Washington Football Stadium Addition Collapse (1987)|url=https://failures.wikispaces.com/University+of+Washington+Football+Stadium+(Manno)|website=failures.wikispaces.com|accessdate=March 24, 2017}} Although there were no casualties, property damage ranged from $500,000 to $1,000,000 and resulted in setbacks.[http://www.historylink.org/essays/output.cfm?file_id=2947 HistoryLink Essay: Husky Stadium collapses on February 25, 1987]{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Y1xWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=CPADAAAAIBAJ&pg=3711%2C4515435|newspaper=[[The Spokesman-Review]]|location=Spokane|title=Section of Husky Stadium Collapses|date=February 26, 1987|page=A-1}} Husky Stadium was a primary venue for the [[1990 Goodwill Games]], where the crowd saw an address by former [[President of the United States|President]] [[Ronald Reagan]], as well as an address by [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]], and a performance by the [[Moody Blues]] & [[Gorky Park (band)|Gorky Park]]. The stadium hosted the opening and closing ceremonies, as well as the track & field competition. Husky Stadium was the temporary home of the [[Seattle Seahawks]] for five games (two preseason and three regular season) in [[1994 NFL season|1994]] while the [[Kingdome]] was temporarily closed for repairs to its damaged roof. After the demolition of the Kingdome in March 2000, the Seahawks played at Husky Stadium for the [[2000 Seattle Seahawks season|2000]] and [[2001 Seattle Seahawks season|2001]] seasons before moving into Seahawks Stadium (now [[CenturyLink Field]]) in [[2002 Seattle Seahawks season|2002]]. The playing field at Husky Stadium was originally dirt, which was then replaced with natural grass in 1938.{{cite news|url=http://www.seattlepi.com/huskies/333325_stadium27.html|title=Husky Stadium Aging Not So Gracefully|newspaper=[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]}} {{Dead link|date=January 2012|bot=RjwilmsiBot}} In [[1968 Washington Huskies football team|1968]], Washington became one of the first major college teams to play on [[AstroTurf]] at home; at the time, the [[Houston, Texas|Houston]] [[Astrodome]] and [[Neyland Stadium]] in [[Knoxville, Tennessee]] were the only major facilities to use the surface. The AstroTurf field was replaced in [[1972 in sports|1972]], [[1977 Washington Huskies football team|1977]], [[1987 Washington Huskies football team|1987]], and [[1995 Washington Huskies football team|1995]].{{cite web|last1=Linde|first1=Richard|title=From rocks to turf: "'Did you ever see a field grow rocks?'"|url=http://www.4malamute.com/stadium2.html|website=4malamute.com|accessdate=March 24, 2017}} [[FieldTurf]], a new variation of synthetic turf, was installed in [[2000 Washington Huskies football team|2000]] at a cost of $1,074,958. The new turf features enhanced drainage and reduced abrasion through the use of synthetic fibers that are tufted into an infill of sand and rubber. The project was funded by [[Seattle Seahawks]] owner [[Paul Allen]], who used Husky Stadium as a temporary home venue during the construction of [[CenturyLink Field]]. The first of its kind in the NFL, the surface was so popular with the players that the Seahawks, who had planned to use natural grass at their new stadium, instead installed their own FieldTurf surface.{{cite web|title=PAUL ALLEN PAYS FOR NEW TURF AT HUSKY STADIUM|url=http://www.fieldturf.com/fr/artificial-turf/artificial-turf-news/paul-allen-pays-for-new-turf-at-husky-stadium|website=fieldturf.com|accessdate=March 24, 2017}} The FieldTurf at Husky Stadium was replaced with a newer one after nine seasons in 2009 at a cost of $350,000.{{cite web|title=Washington To Replace Husky Stadium Playing Surface|url=http://pac-12.com/article/2009/04/17/washington-replace-husky-stadium-playing-surface|website=pac-12.com|accessdate=March 24, 2017}} [[File:Seattle - Husky Stadium under construction - 1920.jpg|frame|center|Husky Stadium under construction in 1920 in front of [[Union Bay (Seattle, Washington)|Union Bay]]]] In addition to the new playing surface, the Seahawks made other improvements to Husky stadium in preparation for its tenure as an NFL venue for two seasons. A larger scoreboard debuted in 1998, with a {{convert|23|x|42|ft|adj=on}} "HuskyTron" video screen. Improved lighting for television, including corner lights, was added in 1999, and official [[National Football League|NFL]] goalposts (optic yellow, {{convert|40|ft|1|abbr=on}} in height) were installed in 2000. The Husky Stadium end zones were painted gold during the 1980s and early 1990s; the new AstroTurf in [[1995 Washington Huskies football team|1995]] changed them to purple. They became natural green with the installation of FieldTurf in [[2000 Washington Huskies football team|2000]], which lasted until 2009 when they reverted to gold for one season. Purple end zones returned prior the [[2010 Washington Huskies football team|2010]] season, and were temporarily painted black for the Huskies' first "blackout" game against [[2010 UCLA Bruins football team|UCLA]] on November 18. On September 3, 2015, [[Alaska Airlines]] purchased naming rights to the field, which changed the official name to "Alaska Airlines Field at Husky Stadium." The agreement, in which the university will receive $41 million over 10 years, became the largest of its kind in college athletics.{{cite web |url=http://www.seattletimes.com/sports/uw-husky-football/uw-alaska-airlines-agree-to-naming-rights-deal-for-husky-stadium/|work=Seattle Times|title=UW, Alaska Airlines agree to naming-rights deal for Husky Stadium’s field|date=September 3, 2015|accessdate=October 17, 2015}} ===The Wave=== {{See also|Wave (audience)}} [[File:2009-0919-HuskyStadium.jpg|thumb|240px|Pre-renovation in 2009, looking south;
Downtown and [[Space Needle]] at top right]] Many claim that the first [[audience wave]] originated in Husky Stadium on [[Halloween]] 1981, at the prompting of Husky band trumpeter Dave Hunter.{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/blog/playbook/fandom/post/_/id/18888/its-settled-where-the-wave-first-started |title=It's settled: Where The Wave first started |publisher=Espn.com |date=2013-03-01 |accessdate=2016-09-21}}{{cite web|author=Daven Hiskey |url=http://www.todayifoundout.com/index.php/2014/07/wave-started/ |title=Who Invented the Sporting Wave? |publisher=Todayifoundout.com |date=2014-07-15 |accessdate=2016-09-21}} Contrary to Hunter's account, former Washington yell leader [[Robb Weller]] has also claimed credit for the first wave.{{cite web|url=https://www.washington.edu/news/archive/uweek/awards2008/42265 |title=Best and Brightest 2008 | University of Washington Recognition Award Recipients |publisher=Washington.edu |date= |accessdate=2016-09-21}}{{cite web|url=http://www.sandiegoreader.com/news/2002/aug/29/who-started-wave/ |title=Who started the wave? |publisher=San Diego Reader |date=2002-08-29 |accessdate=2016-09-21}} Weller was the guest yell-king during the Huskies' homecoming football game against [[1981 Stanford Cardinal football team|Stanford]]. His initial concept for the wave was for it to travel vertically, from the bottom of the stands to the top, within the Husky student section.{{cite web|url=https://espn.go.com/espn/page2/story?page=caple/wave/061027 |title=ESPN.com: Page 2 : Please, don't blame me for this |publisher=Espn.go.com |date=1981-10-15 |accessdate=2016-09-21}} When the stunt was met with limited interest, he then decided to reverse the movement of the wave to travel from top to bottom. This failed miserably, as it was necessary to turn backward to see the wave progressing downward. Weller then gave up and returned his attention to the game. However, a fan named Omar Parker sitting on the open (east) end of the stadium at the student side started yelling "sideways". Weller did not hear him, but then many students tried to initiate a "sideways" wave on their own. After a few attempts, and more yelling of "sideways" by students, Weller took notice. He instructed the crowd to stand as he ran past. He moved along the track toward the open end of the stadium, explaining to the student crowd what he would do, then ran along the track toward the closed end of the stadium, in front of the student section. The stunt caught on after a couple of tries and continued around the entire stadium, and was then repeated throughout the rest of the game and the season. Longtime UW band director Bill Bissell also claimed co-creator credit with Weller, suggesting that the wave was devised by both of them prior to the game. The following week Bill Scott (known as "Bill the Beer Man") started the wave in Husky Stadium and also at the [[Seattle Seahawks]] game in the Kingdome. ===Loudest Stadium in College Football=== [[File:Apple Cup Crowd 1.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Capacity crowd in the south stands
at the 100th [[Apple Cup]] in 2007]] Husky Stadium has long been recognized as one of the loudest stadiums in the nation.{{cite news|last=Miller|first=Ted|title=Getting to know the new Husky Stadium |url=http://espn.go.com/blog/pac10/post/_/id/24135/getting-to-know-the-new-husky-stadium|newspaper=ESPN|date=August 11, 2011}} This is in part due to the stadium's design; almost 70% of the seats are located between the end zones, covered by cantilevered metal roofs that trap the sound.[http://gohuskies.cstv.com/facilities/wash-husky-stadium.html Husky Stadium listing] at official Huskies athletic site At times, the high decibel levels typical of Husky games, in addition to fans stomping their feet in the bleachers, causes television cameras to shake. During the [[1992 Washington Huskies football team|1992 night game]] against the [[1992 Nebraska Cornhuskers football team|Nebraska Cornhuskers]], [[ESPN]] measured the noise level at over 130 [[decibels]], well above the [[threshold of pain]]. The maximum recorded level of 133.6 decibels, according to ESPN, is the highest ever recorded for a college football stadium.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mwE2LyzOvqc|title=Loudest College Football Stadium?|publisher=YouTube|accessdate=July 28, 2012}} ===Tailgating=== Husky Stadium is unusual in that fans can travel to football games by boat, known locally as "sailgating" (other stadiums with this feature include [[Neyland Stadium]] at [[Tennessee Volunteers football|Tennessee]], [[Heinz Field]] at [[Pittsburgh]], and [[McLane Stadium]] at [[Baylor Bears football|Baylor]]). There can be upwards of 12,000 people out on Lake Washington next to Husky Stadium during game days.[http://stats.washingtonpost.com/cfb/story.asp?i=20071010155457251988104 Tim Booth AP Sports Writer] Before kickoff, the Washington crew team offers shuttles to anyone that wants to go to and from the boats and docks for the game.[http://www.idahostatesman.com/boisestatefootball/story/151085.html IdahoStatesman.com] The north and south parking lots are packed with cars for [[tailgate party|tailgating]]. There is currently controversy surrounding the south parking lot because the Pacific Interchange Option for expansion to the [[Evergreen Point Floating Bridge (2016)|SR 520 Floating Bridge]] would effectively eliminate the south parking lot for tailgating. Fans also gather at the Dempsey Indoor Facility just north of the stadium for Husky Huddles. After the game, the Tyee Sports Council and the University of Washington Athletic Department put on events where fans can gather and hear analysis of the game from Washington coaches and Husky Legends, and listen to the Husky Marching Band. ===2011–2013 renovation=== [[File:Aerial Husky Stadium April 6 2012.jpg|thumb|right|Renovation in April 2012]] Husky Stadium had developed numerous structural problems over the years as a result of standing for nine decades in Seattle's moist weather, particularly in the lower bowl. In November 2011, Husky Stadium began a $261 million renovation, the largest single capital project in the history of the University of Washington.{{cite news |last=Thiel |first=Art |title=Thiel: UW Stadium Funding Near Goal Line|url=http://sportspressnw.com/2110589/2011/thiel-uw-stadium-funding-nearing-goal-line|newspaper=Sports Press Northwest|date=August 10, 2011}} Home games were played at [[CenturyLink Field]] during the [[2012 Washington Huskies football team|2012]] season while construction took place.{{cite news|last=Condotta|first=Bob|title=New Husky Stadium: on time, on budget |url=http://seattletimes.com/html/huskyfootball/2018987898_huskystadium25.html |newspaper=The Seattle Times|date=August 24, 2012}} The [[Apple Cup]] in [[2011 Washington Huskies football team|2011]] was moved to CenturyLink to advance the start of the project by several weeks. The new Husky Stadium was developed by Wright Runstad & Company, designed by [[360 Architecture]], and constructed by [[Turner Construction]] company. The steel decking was supplied by Profile Steel. The new stadium is the first and primary income source of a completely remodeled athletic district which includes a new $19 million [[Husky Ballpark]], a new track and field stadium, renovated soccer stadium, $50 million basketball operations and practice facility and recently completed projects such as the Husky Legends Center, the [[Conibear Shellhouse]] and Alaska Airlines Arena renovations, and the construction of the Dempsey Indoor facility. This major remodel of the athletic village coincided with construction for an underground station for a northern extension of the [[Link Light Rail]] system and a [[Evergreen Point Floating Bridge (2016)|replacement]] of the [[Evergreen Point Floating Bridge]]. The renovation project incorporated a new grand concourse, press box, video and audio system, and football offices, as well as new and improved amenities, concession stands, and bathrooms. The track that had enclosed the playing field was removed, and the field itself lowered by four feet to make room for additional seating closer to the sidelines. The student section was relocated from the north sideline to the west end zone, and the temporary bleachers in the east end zone were replaced with a permanent structure featuring field-level suites. The addition of box suites reduced the seating capacity from 72,500 to 70,138.[https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/ncaaf/pac12/2013/08/29/husky-stadium-university-of-washington-renovations-debut-boise-state/2725873/ "Husky Stadium to debut after $280M renovation". ''USA Today'']. Associated Press. August 29, 2013. Retrieved September 1, 2013. Despite the reduction in capacity, the renovated stadium is expected to be as loud as its predecessor.Gall, Braden [http://athlonsports.com/college-football/ranking-pac-12s-college-football-stadiums Ranking the Pac-12's College Football Stadiums]. [[Athlon Sports]], 2013-06-13. Additionally, new parking garages were constructed and facilities throughout the athletic village were renovated.{{cite news|url=http://archives.seattletimes.nwsource.com/cgi-bin/texis.cgi/web/vortex/display?slug=uwfacilities01&date=20061201|newspaper=[[The Seattle Times]] |first=Bob |last=Condotta|title=UW Athletic Director Unveils New Husky Stadium Drawings|date=December 1, 2006}} ==Seattle Seahawks== The [[National Football League|NFL's]] [[Seattle Seahawks]] first played home games at Husky Stadium in [[1994 Seattle Seahawks season|1994]], while unplanned repairs were made to the interior ceiling of the [[Kingdome]]. A total of five Seahawk games were at Husky Stadium; two pre-season and three regular season. The Kingdome reopened for the final five home games, starting on November 6. The Seahawks later played the [[2000 Seattle Seahawks season|2000]] and [[2001 Seattle Seahawks season|2001]] seasons at Husky Stadium while their new home, Seahawks Stadium (now [[CenturyLink Field]]), was constructed on the footprint of the demolished Kingdome. ==NFL exhibition games== Between 1955 and 1975, Husky Stadium hosted 12 NFL preseason games. The [[San Francisco 49ers]] played six times at the stadium, the most of any team. Other teams to make multiple appearances include the [[New York Giants]], [[Los Angeles Rams]], [[Cleveland Browns]], and [[Arizona Cardinals|Chicago/St. Louis Cardinals]].{{cite web |first=Andrew |last=McKillop |url=http://www.footballgeography.com/nfl-exhibition-games-played-at-neutral-sites/|title=NFL Exhibition Games Played at Neutral Sites » FootballGeography.com: Includes Non-League Away Games and/or Games Played at Non-League Stadiums|publisher=FootballGeography.com|accessdate=August 31, 2013}} At one point after the [[1970 NFL season]], [[Ralph Wilson]] came close to moving the [[Buffalo Bills]] from dilapidated [[War Memorial Stadium (Buffalo)|War Memorial Stadium]] to Husky Stadium.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1876&dat=19710115&id=ezMsAAAAIBAJ&sjid=xMsEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4930,2267693|newspaper=Spartanburg (SC) Herald |title=Memphis, Tampa express interest in Buffalo Bills |agency=Associated Press |date=January 15, 1971 |page=14 }} The threat of relocation prompted the developers in the Buffalo suburbs to construct Rich Stadium (later Ralph Wilson Stadium and now [[New Era Field]]), which opened in 1973. The Bills have resided there ever since. ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I FBS football stadiums]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ===Further reading=== * {{cite news|last=Condotta|first=Bob|title=Huskies hope this facelift takes them back to the top|url=http://seattletimes.com/html/take2/2015870752_the_start_of_a_new.html|newspaper=[[The Seattle Times]]|date=August 10, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141011013938/http://seattletimes.com/html/take2/2015870752_the_start_of_a_new.html|archivedate=October 11, 2014|df=}} * {{cite news|last=Condotta|first=Bob|title=Will tickets to new Husky Stadium cost a lot more?|url=http://seattletimes.com/html/huskies/2015876084_uwfb11.html|newspaper=[[The Seattle Times]] |date=August 10, 2011}} * {{cite news|last=Condotta|first=Bob|title=UW athletic director unveils new Husky Stadium drawings|url=http://seattletimes.com/html/sports/2003456124_uwfacilities01.html|newspaper=[[The Seattle Times]]|date=December 1, 2006}} ==External links== {{commons category|Husky Stadium}} * [http://www.gohuskies.com/ViewArticle.dbml?ATCLID=208568068 Husky Stadium profile at Washington Huskies official website] {{s-start}} {{succession box | title = Home of the [[Seattle Seahawks]] | years = First half of 1994
2000 – 2001 | before = [[Kingdome|The Kingdome]]
[[Kingdome|The Kingdome]] | after = [[Kingdome|The Kingdome]]
[[CenturyLink Field]] }} {{end}} {{Navboxes |title = Articles related to Husky Stadium |titlestyle = {{CollegePrimaryStyle|Washington Huskies|color=white}} |list = {{Washington Huskies football navbox}} {{University of Washington}} {{Pacific-12 Conference football venue navbox}} {{Seattle Seahawks}} {{Washington college football venues}} {{Defunct NFL stadiums}} }} [[Category:Washington Huskies football venues]] [[Category:College football venues]] [[Category:American football venues in Washington (state)]] [[Category:Defunct National Football League venues]] [[Category:Seattle Seahawks stadiums]] [[Category:Sports venues in Seattle]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1920]] [[Category:1920 establishments in Washington (state)]] [[Category:1990 Goodwill Games venues]] [[Category:University of Washington campus]]

{{flagicon|GER}} [[Jens Deimel]] (100 m) | championships = | olympics = | world championships = }} '''Kanzlersgrund ski jump hills''' or '''Schanzenanlage im Kanzlersgrund''' (also ''Hans-Renner-Schanze'', ''Rennsteigschanze'' or ''Schanze am Rennsteig'') are [[ski jumping]] hills in [[Oberhof, Germany]]. ==History== Large hill was opened in 1959 and normal in 1987 and are owned by WSW Oberhof 05. It hosted four [[Fédération Internationale de Ski|FIS]] [[Ski jumping World Cup]] events in 1989, 1991 and 2005 and more world cup events in Nordic combined. [[Anssi Koivuranta]] holds the hill record which is also the world record set on plastic mate. {{coord|50.6967|N|10.6803|E|source:wikidata|display=title}} [[Category:Ski jumping venues in Germany]] [[Category:Sports venues in Thuringia]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1959]] [[Category:1959 establishments in Germany]] [[Category:1987 establishments in Germany]]

revision.text: {{Infobox sport supporter group | name = Udruženje Bordo prijatelji 1946 | full name = | image = File:Bordo.prijatelji.jpg | caption = | nickname = | abbreviation = UBP1946 | founded = 2010 | type = [[Supporters' groups|Fan group]], [[Advocacy group]] | stand = | motto = | headquarters = [[Sarajevo]], [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]] | team = [[FK Sarajevo]] | arenas = | colors = | website = [http://www.bordoprijatelji.ba Official website] }} '''Maroon Friends 1946''' ({{lang-bs|'Bordo prijatelji 1946'}}) is an [[FK Sarajevo]] fan association and [[advocacy group]] organized by influential individuals from the financial, political and cultural sectors of Bosnian society with the aim of lobbying both locally and internationally for the club and influencing club policies.{{cite news | date=26 July 2011 | url=http://www.bordoprijatelji.ba/index.php/o-nama | title=O nama | work=Official website | accessdate=28 July 2016 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160803184711/http://www.bordoprijatelji.ba/index.php/o-nama | archivedate=3 August 2016 | df= }} The association has strong informal ties to FK Sarajevo [[Ultras]], [[Horde Zla]].{{cite news |url=http://sport.ba/clanak/181674/jedna-od-najuspjesnijih-godina-u-historiji-bordo-kluba |title=Jedna od najuspješnijih godina u historiji kluba |work=Sport.ba |date=29 July 2016 }} ==History== In 2009 a handful of eminent supporters of FK Sarajevo, including fashion designer [[Haad (Adnan Hajrulahović)|Adnan Hajrulahović]], poet and musician [[Benjamin Isović]], entrepreneur Avdo Salihbegović and others started having informal meetings about the possibility of organizing a new supporter's association with the goal of helping the club.{{cite news |url=http://www.klix.ba/sport/kako-su-nastali-bordo-prijatelji-vizionari-koji-su-cetiri-godine-vodili-bitku-za-bolje-sarajevo/150613044 |title=Kako su nastali Bordo prijatelji: Vizionari koji su četiri godine vodili bitku za bolje Sarajevo |work=Klix.ba |date=29 July 2016 }} These meetings led to the formal registration of an Association of Citizens in 2010, which quickly struck a strong partnership with the club's Ultras group, [[Horde zla]]. After a thorough analysis of club finances and the announced shift in [[UEFA]] licensing, the association came to the conclusion that the club would be in a dire situation by 2012.{{cite news |url=http://www.klix.ba/sport/kako-su-nastali-bordo-prijatelji-vizionari-koji-su-cetiri-godine-vodili-bitku-za-bolje-sarajevo/150613044 |title=Kako su nastali Bordo prijatelji: Vizionari koji su četiri godine vodili bitku za bolje Sarajevo |work=Klix.ba |date=29 July 2016 }}{{cite news |url=http://www.klix.ba/sport/nogomet/bordo-prijatelji-1946-fk-sarajevo-je-brand/100419108 |title=Bordo prijatelji 1946: "FK Sarajevo je brand" |work=Klix.ba |date=29 July 2016 }} After the founding Assembly a platform and organizational plan were forged under the working title ''Projekt 2010-2014''.{{cite news |url=http://fksinfo.com/novosti/predstavljamo-bordo-prijatelji-1946/985 |title=Predstavljamo: Bordo prijatelji 1946 |work=Fksinfo.com |date=29 July 2016 }} The association wrote a new template for the club's statute and found bureaucratic loopholes in Bosnia's law in order to potentially attract foreign investment seeing the country has no [[Sport policies of the European Union|Sports Law]].{{cite news |url=http://sportsport.ba/bh_fudbal/prijedlog-novog-statuta-fk-sarajevo/79848 |title=Prijedlog novog statuta FK Sarajevo |work=Sportsport.ba |date=29 July 2016 }} FK Sarajevo's management at the time, witnessing the association's polyvalence, quickly invited members to join the club's assembly and board, which they did. On 14 July 2012 the new club statute was voted into power, enabling [[Malaysia]]n businessman, investor and Chairman of [[Berjaya Group]], [[Vincent Tan]], who had earlier been lobbied by [[Scotiabank]] director and association member [[Edis Kusturica|Feđa Kusturica]], to buy majority stocks and become ''de facto'' owner of the club.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2013/dec/25/cardiff-city-vincent-tan-bosnia |title=Cardiff City owner Vincent Tan takes control of club in Bosnia |newspaper=The Guardian |date=25 December 2013 }}{{cite news |url=http://www.fksarajevo.ba/bs/vijesti/novi-statut-fudbalskog-kluba-sarajevo/714 |title=Novi STATUT Fudbalskog Kluba Sarajevo |work=FK Sarajevo Official website |date=29 July 2016 }} ==Media== Maroon Friends 1946 has been publishing a monthly magazine named ''Maroon Fan'' ({{lang-bs|Bordo Fan}}) since 2010.{{cite news |url=http://www.klix.ba/sport/nogomet/izasao-drugi-broj-magazina-bordo-fan/110610122 |title= Izašao drugi broj magazina "Bordo fan" |work=Klix.ba |date=29 July 2016 }} Furthermore, it has in cooperation with [[Moja TV]], an [[IPTV]] provider and subsidiary of the [[BH Telecom]], founded an internet-based television channel named ''Bordo TV''.{{cite news |url=http://www.bordoprijatelji.ba/index.php/bordo-fan |title= Bordo Fan TV |work=Official website |date=29 July 2016 }} ==Bodies== ===Presidency=== ''As of 29 July 2016'' {{cite news |url=http://www.bordoprijatelji.ba/index.php/o-nama |title=Sastav Bordo prijatelja |work=Official website |date=29 July 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160803184711/http://www.bordoprijatelji.ba/index.php/o-nama |archivedate=3 August 2016 |df= }} {| class="wikitable" |- ! Name ! Position |- | [[Benjamin Isović]] | Chairman |- | Senad Kapetanović | Vice-chairman |- | Avdo Salihbegović | General Secretary |- | Adis Mešić | Member |- | Eldin Karić | Member |- | Senad Kadić | Member |- | Kenan Agić | Member |- | Dino Mahić | Member |- | Armin Skalonja | Member |} ===Assembly=== ''As of 29 July 2016'' {{cite news |url=http://www.bordoprijatelji.ba/index.php/o-nama |title=Sastav Bordo prijatelja |work=Official website |date=29 July 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160803184711/http://www.bordoprijatelji.ba/index.php/o-nama |archivedate=3 August 2016 |df= }} {| |- | width="10" |  | valign="top" | {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center" |- !|Name !|Years |- | align="left" |Samir Hadžić | align="left" |Chairman |- |Sead Bašić | align="left" |Member |- | align="left" |Rešad Muratović | align="left" |Member |- | align="left" |[[Edis Kusturica|Feđa Kusturica]] | align="left" |Member |- | align="left" |[[Slaviša Vukićević]] | align="left" |Member |- | align="left" |[[Edis Kusturica]] | align="left" |Member |- | align="left" |Elmedin Konaković | align="left" |Member |- | align="left" |Amir Rizvanović | align="left" |Member |- | align="left" |Reuf Karabeg | align="left" |Member |- | align="left" |Dževad Bećirević | align="left" |Member |- | align="left" |[[Alen Hujić]] | align="left" |Member |} |} revision.text:
[[File:Pitching machine.jpg|thumb|250px|A hand-fed pitching machine]] A '''pitching machine''' is a machine that automatically [[pitch (baseball)|pitches]] a [[baseball (object)|baseball]] to a [[batting (baseball)|batter]] at different speeds and styles. Most machines are hand-fed, but there are some that automatically feed. There are multiple types of pitching machines; softball, baseball, youth, adult, and a combination of both softball and baseball.
==History== In 1897, mathematics instructor [[Charles Hinton]] designed a gunpowder-powered baseball pitching machine for the [[Princeton University]] baseball team's batting practice.<ref>Hinton, Charles, "A Mechanical Pitcher", [[Harper's Weekly]], March 20, 1897, p. 301–302</ref> According to one source it caused several injuries, and may have been in part responsible for Hinton's dismissal from Princeton that year.<ref>Physics in Higher-Dimensional Manifolds [http://www.uwspace.uwaterloo.ca/bitstream/10012/1276/1/ssseahra2003.pdf bottom page 5]</ref> However, the machine was versatile: it was capable of throwing variable speeds with an adjustable breech size and firing curve balls by the use of two rubber-coated steel fingers at the muzzle of the pitcher.<ref>Hinton, Charles, "The Motion of a Baseball", ''The Yearbook of the Minneapolis Society of Engineers'', May 1908, p. 18–28</ref> Hinton successfully introduced the machine to the [[University of Minnesota]] where he worked as an assistant professor until 1900.
The arm-type pitching machine was designed by Paul Giovagnoli in 1952, for use on his driving range. Using a metal arm mounted to a large gear, this type of machine simulates the motion of an actual pitcher, throwing balls with consistent speed and direction. One- and two-wheel style machines were originally patented by Bartley N. Marty in 1916. <ref>US Patent 1211738[http://www.freepatentsonline.com/1211738.html]</ref> <ref>US Patent 1204468[http://www.freepatentsonline.com/1204468.html]</ref>
==Design== Pitching machines come in a variety of styles. However, the two most popular machines are an arm action machine and a circular wheel machine. The arm action machine simulates the delivery of a pitcher and carries a ball at the end of a bracket, much like a hand would. The arm action machine then delivers the ball in an overhand motion. The circular wheel machine contains one, two or three wheels that spin much like a bike tire. The wheels on these machines are usually set in either a horizontal or vertical fashion. With a circular machine, a ball shoots out towards the hitter after it is fed into the wheel or wheels. Three-wheel machines are more easily adjusted to be able to throw a variety of pitches and they can be used for a wide range of other practice scenarios, such as ground work or flyballs.
The use of pitching machines allows baseball and softball players the opportunity to get batting practice on their own. Most batting machines are set up in a [[batting cage]], a netted area that will contain the balls after they are hit. By using a pitching machine and a batting cage, hitters can get a huge number of batting reps without having to drag other players out to a baseball field or wear out the arms of team pitchers or coaches. The cost of pitching machines varies greatly.
==Use in Little League== In the youngest divisions of Little League, and other youth baseball organizations, pitching machines are used instead of live pitching. This is done to give the kids more experience hitting the ball, as pitchers at that age would tend to throw few strikes. Simple spring-loaded manual models are common (such as from Louisville Slugger) as are battery-powered compressed-air machines (such as from Zooka).
==Notes== <references/>
{{Baseball}}
[[Category:Baseball equipment]] [[Category:Baseball pitching]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox racehorse | horsename = The Merry Monarch | image_name = The Merry Monarch 1.jpg | caption = The Merry Monarch with jockey Foster Bell. Painting by Francis Calcraft Turner. | sire = Slane | grandsire = Royal Oak | dam = The Margravine | damsire = Little John | sex = [[Stallion (horse)|Stallion]] | foaled = 1842 | country = [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland]] | colour = [[Bay (horse)|Bay]] | breeder = G. W. Gratwicke | owner = G. W. Gratwicke | trainer = John Forth | record = 4:1-1-0 | earnings = | race = [[Epsom Derby]] (1845) | awards = | honours = |updated= }} '''The Merry Monarch''' (1842 – after 1859) was a British [[Thoroughbred]] racehorse and [[Horse breeding#Terminology|sire]]. In a career that lasted from July 1844 to May 1846 he ran four times and won only one race. That race, however, was the 1845 [[Epsom Derby]], in which he recorded an unexpected victory. After one race in 1846 he was retired to [[stud (animal)|stud]] where he made no impression as a sire. ==Background== The Merry Monarch was a bay horse bred by his owner, William Gratwicke of Ham Manor, near [[Angmering]] in [[Sussex]]. Gratwicke also bred his dam, The Margravine, who was a sister to the 1829 Derby winner [[Frederick (horse)|Frederick]]. His sire, Slane, was runner-up in the [[Ascot Gold Cup]] and, thanks largely to The Merry Monarch's Derby win, was [[Leading sire in Great Britain and Ireland|Champion sire]] in 1845.{{cite web|url=http://www.tbheritage.com/HistoricSires/LeadingSires/GBLeadSires.html |title=Leading Sires of Great Britain and Ireland |publisher=Tbheritage.com |date= |accessdate=2012-01-15}} The Merry Monarch was sent into training with [[John Forth|John "Daddy" Forth]] who, at the age of sixty,{{cite web |url=http://www.epsomderby.org/facts-and-figures.php |title=Facts and Figures |publisher=Epsomderby.org |date= |accessdate=2012-01-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111223033550/http://www.epsomderby.org/facts-and-figures.php |archivedate=2011-12-23 |df= }} had trained and ridden Frederick in the Derby. Gratwicke's horses were based at [[Goodwood, West Sussex|Goodwood]] at a stable owned by the [[Charles Gordon-Lennox, 5th Duke of Richmond|Duke of Richmond]]. Following a disagreement with the Duke,{{cite book | last1 = Mortimer | first1 = Roger |last2=Onslow|first2=Richard|last3=Willett|first3=Peter| title = Biographical Encyclopedia of British Flat Racing| publisher=Macdonald and Jane’s | year = 1978| isbn = 0-354-08536-0}} Gratwicke moved his horses to [[Newmarket, Suffolk]]. ==Racing career== ===1844: two-year-old season=== On his first racecourse appearance, The Merry Monarch ran in the Ham Stakes at [[Goodwood Racecourse|Goodwood]] in July. He finished unplaced behind Refraction, a filly who went on to win [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] in 1845.{{cite web|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article59763996?|title=04 Oct 1845 - THE DERBY STAKES AT EPSOM, 1845 |publisher=Trove.nla.gov.au |date= |accessdate=2012-01-14}} ===1845: three-year-old season=== The Merry Monarch's first race of 1846 was the Derby at [[Epsom Downs Racecourse|Epsom]]. The build-up to the race was marred by reports of a plot to either lame or poison Old England, one of the favourites for the race, while another one of the leading contenders, The Libel, was allegedly drugged ("doctored").{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=I3AXAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA476&dq=%22the+merry+monarch%22+derby&hl=en&sa=X&ei=_csRT7OSBIaX8gPl58jxAw&ved=0CGIQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=%22the%20merry%20monarch%22%20&f=false |title=The Sportsman's magazine of life in London and the country - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-01-14}} Poor weather on the morning of the race did not deter the crowd, which was reported to be as large and unruly as ever.{{cite web|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article59764672?|title=11 Oct 1845 - THE DERBY DAY, MAY 28, 1845 |publisher=Trove.nla.gov.au |date= |accessdate=2012-01-14}} Ridden by the little-known Foster Bell, The Merry Monarch started at odds of [[Fixed odds betting#Fractional odds|15/1]] in a record field of thirty one runners. These official odds however, were offered jointly for The Merry Monarch and his stable companion Doleful:{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PSkGAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA445&dq=%22the+merry+monarch%22+derby&hl=en&sa=X&ei=_csRT7OSBIaX8gPl58jxAw&ved=0CDkQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=%22the%20merry%20monarch%22%20derby&f=false |title=The Sportsman - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-01-14}} according to ''The Sporting Magazine'', odds of 35/1 would have been more accurate reflection of the actual betting.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jBQGAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA435&dq=%22the+merry+monarch%22+derby&hl=en&sa=X&ei=pNMRT_u0DYj_8QOB0NDKAw&ved=0CGMQ6AEwCTgU#v=onepage&q=%22the%20merry%20monarch%22%20derby&f=false |title=The Sporting magazine; or Monthly calendar of the transactions of the turf ... - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-01-14}} The start of the race was delayed by almost an hour by a series of false starts and an incident in which one of the leading contenders, Alarm was kicked by The Libel. Alarm threw off his jockey, Nat Flatman, ran into a chain fence and then galloped loose down the course for several minutes before being caught. Both Alarm and Flatman were injured, but took part in the race when it eventually got under way. The Merry Monarch was among the leading group from the start, and was in fourth place at the turn into the straight, where one horse fell and several others were badly hampered.{{cite web|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article59764701?|title=11 Oct 1845 - THE RACE |publisher=Trove.nla.gov.au |date= |accessdate=2012-01-14}} Approaching the final [[furlong]], Bell sent The Merry Monarch to the front and he established a clear lead before staying on well to win "in clever style" by a length from Annandale, with Old England a neck away in third.{{cite web|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article8757389?|title=26 Sep 1845 - THE DERBY AND OAKS. Odds before the start |publisher=Trove.nla.gov.au |date= |accessdate=2012-01-14}} The result was a major surprise to most observers, including, it was reported, the winner's own connections,{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uIMEAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA383&dq=%22the+merry+monarch%22+derby&hl=en&sa=X&ei=r9ERT_7CDsir8QPV5tnfAw&ved=0CFYQ6AEwBzgK#v=onepage&q=%22the%20merry%20monarch%22%20derby&f=false |title=The New sporting magazine - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-01-14}} who had believed that their other runner, Doleful, had the better chance of winning. In July, The Merry Monarch was sent to Goodwood for the Gratwicke Stakes. He finished second, beaten a head by Hersey,{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kjsGAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA499&dq=%22the+merry+monarch%22+goodwood+%22gratwicke+stakes%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=c9wRT7yNIYXU8gPB4dj1Aw&sqi=2&ved=0CEIQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=%22the%20merry%20monarch%22%20goodwood%20%22gratwicke%20stakes%22&f=false |title=The Sportsman's magazine of life in London and the country, ed., by Miles's Boy - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-01-14}} a mare whose only previous win had come in a "fifty pound plate".{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4YoEAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA60&dq=%22the+merry+monarch%22+derby&hl=en&sa=X&ei=_csRT7OSBIaX8gPl58jxAw&ved=0CFMQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=%22the%20merry%20monarch%22&f=false |title=The Sporting review, ed. by 'Craven'. - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-01-14}} Despite his defeat, The Merry Monarch remained among the leading fancies for the [[St. Leger Stakes|St Leger]], but he did not appear again that year. The Merry Monarch's prize of £3,975 for the Derby was enough to make him the third highest money winner of the British season behind Refraction and Sweetmeat.{{cite web|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article27453378?|title=29 Jul 1846 - SPORTING |publisher=Trove.nla.gov.au |date= |accessdate=2012-01-14}} ===1846: four-year-old season=== On his only race as a four-year-old, The Merry Monarch returned to Epsom for the Grand Stand Plate, a mile and a quarter handicap on the day after the Derby. Carrying top weight of 118 [[Pound (mass)|pounds]], he finished unplaced behind an unnamed colt owned by [[James Merry (Scottish politician)|James Merry]].{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FuQNAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA69&dq=%22the+merry+monarch%22+derby&hl=en&sa=X&ei=3tQRT8SzLo7y8QOo9IWCBA&ved=0CDMQ6AEwADge#v=onepage&q=%22the%20merry%20monarch%22%20derby&f=false |title=the racing calendar for the year 1846 - charles and james weatherby - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-01-14}} Before the end of the year, The Merry Monarch changed hands three times. Following his run at Epsom he was bought by [[Lord George Bentinck]], but a month later, Bentinck decided to give up his racing interests to concentrate on politics and sold all his horses for £10,000 to [[Edward Lloyd-Mostyn, 2nd Baron Mostyn|Edward Lloyd-Mostyn]]. The Merry Monarch was put up for auction and bought back by his original owner, William Gratwicke for 78 [[Guinea (British coin)|guineas]].{{cite web|author=Patricia Erigero Thoroughbred Heritage |url=http://www.tbheritage.com/Portraits/Slane.html#MerryMonarch |title=Slane |publisher=Tbheritage.com |date= |accessdate=2012-01-14}} ==Assessment== ''The Sportsman'' magazine described The Merry Monarch as "a very bad horse" and his Derby win as the biggest "fluke" in the history of the race. ''The Farmer's Magazine'' concurred, calling the result "one of the greatest flukes that we have on record".{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=er-9XUjaNn4C&pg=PA474-IA2&dq=%22the+merry+monarch%22+derby&hl=en&sa=X&ei=_csRT7OSBIaX8gPl58jxAw&ved=0CEQQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=%22the%20merry%20monarch%22%20derby&f=false |title=The Farmer's Magazine - Rogerson & Tuxford - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-01-14}} ==Stud career== The Merry Monarch stood as a stallion at his owner's stud at Ham, where his fee was initially 10 guineas. He attracted few mares however, and in only his second year at stud, he was covering mares at no fee apart from "a [[sovereign (British coin)|sovereign]] for the groom".{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5OsNAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA405&dq=%22the+merry+monarch%22+derby&hl=en&sa=X&ei=EtcRT6ndDsWD8gPLg5iHBA&ved=0CDMQ6AEwADgy#v=onepage&q=%22the%20merry%20monarch%22%20derby&f=false |title=the racing calendar for the year 1848 - charles and james weatherby - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-01-14}} He was the damsire of a filly named Bertha, who finished second in the [[1000 Guineas]] and won the [[Nassau Stakes]] in 1862, but otherwise made no impact. ==Pedigree== {{Pedigree |name = The Merry Monarch (GB), bay stallion, 1842 |inf = |f = Slane (GB)
1833 |m = The Margravine(GB)
1830 |ff = Royal Oak
1823 |fm = Orville mare
1819 |mf = Little John
1816 |mm = Phantom mare
1815 |fff = Catton |ffm = Smolensko mare |fmf = '''[[Orville (horse)|Orville]]*''' |fmm = Epsom Lass |mff = Octavius |mfm = Grey Skim |mmf = [[Phantom (horse)|Phantom]] |mmm = Gohanna mare |ffff = Golumpus |fffm = Lucy Gray |ffmf = [[Smolensko (horse)|Smolensko]] |ffmm = Lady Mary |fmff = Beningbrough |fmfm = Evelina |fmmf = [[Sir Peter Teazle]] |fmmm = Alexina |mfff = '''Orville*''' |mffm = Marianne |mfmf = Woodpecker |mfmm = Milsintown's Herod mare |mmff = Walton |mmfm = Julia |mmmf = [[Gohanna]] |mmmm = Chestnut Skim (Family:5-a){{cite web|url=http://www.bloodlines.net/TB/Families/Family5a.htm |title=Young Hag - Family 5-a |publisher=Bloodlines.net |date= |accessdate=2012-01-14}}}} *The Merry Monarch was [[inbreeding|inbred]] 3 × 4 to Orville. This means that the stallion appears in both the third and fourth generations of his pedigree. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Epsom Derby Winners}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Merry Monarch}} [[Category:1842 racehorse births]] [[Category:19th-century racehorse deaths]] [[Category:Racehorses trained in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Racehorses bred in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Thoroughbred family 5-a]] [[Category:Epsom Derby winners]]

4,050 (smaller hall, basketball) | dimensions = }} '''Tivoli Hall''' ({{lang-sl|Hala Tivoli}}) is a complex of two multi-purpose indoor sport arenas in [[Tivoli City Park]] in [[Ljubljana]], the capital of [[Slovenia]]. The complex was opened in 1965. The larger, [[ice hockey]] arena has a [[seating capacity]] of 4,000 people. When configured to host [[basketball]] games, the capacity is adjusted to 5,600. This hall hosted home games of the professional basketball team [[KK Union Olimpija]] until 2011. The smaller basketball hall has a seating capacity of 4,050 people. The larger one is the home of [[HDD Olimpija Ljubljana]] professional [[ice hockey]] club. ==Events== Regular sporting events include: *[[HK Olimpija]] (ice hockey) *[[KK Union Olimpija]] (basketball); second home venue after [[Arena Stožice]]. *[[KD Ilirija|Ilirija]] (basketball); since the 2017–18 season. revision.text:
[[Image:Torpedo system.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Schematic demonstrating the '''torpedo system'''. The offensive team is moving from right to left. The torpedoes are marked T, halfbacks are marked H, the defenseman, or libero is marked D, and the goaltender is marked G.]]
The '''torpedo system''' is an [[ice hockey]] on-ice system first used by the Swedish team [[Djurgårdens IF Hockey|Djurgårdens IF]]. The coach of Djurgårdens IF, [[Hardy Nilsson]], took the system with him and it was used extensively by the [[Sweden national men's ice hockey team|Swedish national hockey team]] in [[IIHF|international competition]].<ref name=Klein>{{cite web|title=THE YEAR IN IDEAS: A TO Z.; The Torpedo|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E0CE4DD143CF93AA35751C1A9679C8B63|accessdate=2008-01-04|author=Jeff Z. Klein|date= December 9, 2001|work= |publisher=New York Times}}</ref> The system converts the traditional hockey layout of three forwards and two defensemen, into two ''torpedoes'' up front, two ''halfbacks'', and one lone defenceman (or ''libero''). The torpedoes are responsible for [[forecheck|forechecking]] in the corners when the puck is in the offensive zone, and stay around the neutral zone to be sprung into a scoring position (by a ''stretch pass'' or ''torpedo pass''). The halfbacks are all-purpose players that run the offense from the faceoff circles in the offensive zone, and defend against the other team's torpedoes. The libero protects the rear of the ice.<ref name=Slate>{{cite web|title=Damn the Torpedo|url=http://www.slate.com/id/2060571/|accessdate=2008-01-04|author=Ben McGrath|date=January 10, 2002|work=|publisher=Slate magazine}}</ref>
The system is used in international hockey by the Swedish team, due to the large ice surface, and the lack of a [[two-line pass]] offside (which would stop play with a two-line pass). It contrasted the [[neutral zone trap]], which was popular in the 1990s, and which stifled fast skating and playmaking by crowding the neutral zone with players. The system was originated by the [[Boston Bruins]] of the late 1950s; it was later adopted by the [[Chicago Blackhawks]] during the 1960s. The torpedo mode could not be completely implemented in the [[National Hockey League]] until 2005 when the [[red line (hockey)|red line]] was eliminated, allowing for [[two-line pass|two-line passes]] to spring the torpedoes.
The system was used to describe the Swedish national men's hockey team's approach during the [[Ice hockey at the 2002 Winter Olympics|2002 Winter Games]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/olympics/2002/ice_hockey/news/2002/02/15/sweden_canada_ap/|title=Torpedo blast|accessdate=2007-12-31|author= Associated Press|date=February 15, 2002|work=|publisher=CNN/Sports Illustrated}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9804EEDF103FF935A25751C0A9649C8B63|title=Swedish Offense Easily Dismantles Talented Canadian Team |accessdate=2007-12-31|author=Joe Lapointe|date=February 16, 2002|publisher=New York Times}}</ref> which was punctuated by a preliminary 5-2 win over the eventual gold-medal winning Canadian team.
==References== <references/>
==External links== *[http://www.pittsburghpostgazette.com/pg/07066/767530-383.stm Torpedo pass used in game summary] *[http://www.hockeycanada.ca/3/1/2/5/index1.shtml Another example of use in a match summary] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20051215091913/http://www.keneskysports.com/cyclones/newsdetail.html Another use in a match summary]

{{Infobox film | name = Undisputed | image = Undisputed (movie poster).jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Walter Hill (director)|Walter Hill]] | producer = Walter Hill

[[Peter Falk]]
[[Michael Rooker]]
[[TRU (group)|TRU]]
[[Jon Seda]]
[[Wes Studi]] | music = [[Stanley Clarke]] | cinematography = [[Lloyd Ahern II]] | editing = Freeman A. Davies
Phil Norden | studio = [[Millennium Films]]
[[Motion Picture Corporation of America]]
[[A Band Apart]]
[[@radical.media]] | distributor = [[Miramax Films]] | released = {{Film date|2002|08|23}} | runtime = 96 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = $15-$20 million {{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/08/23/movies/at-the-movies.html |title=AT THE MOVIES: A Terrible Beauty |last=Kehr |first=Dave |newspaper=New York Times |date= 23 August 2002 |page=E8 }} | gross = $15,220,548https://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=undisputed.htm
64,579 admissions (France)[http://translate.google.com.au/translate?hl=en&sl=fr&u=http://www.boxofficestory.com/&prev=search Box office figures for Walter Hill films in France] at Box Office Story }} '''''Undisputed''''' is a 2002 American [[drama film|drama]] [[List of sports films|sports film]] written, produced and directed by [[Walter Hill (director)|Walter Hill]] and starring [[Wesley Snipes]] and [[Ving Rhames]]. It was released in the United States on August 23, 2002. The film performed poorly at the box-office and received mixed reviews from critics; nevertheless it later found success in the [[home video market]] and began a film saga with a [[direct-to-video]] [[sequel]] without any of the original cast members. ==Plot== Undisputed [[heavyweight]] [[boxing]] champion George "Iceman" Chambers (Rhames) is convicted of rape and sentenced to a new prison in the desert, called Sweetwater. The high-security facility is populated by hardened criminals. Unaware of the prison's ways and its unique hierarchy, the pompous and bratty Chambers tries to impress upon the inmates his status as a champion boxer. The prison camp, within its own walls, has a riveting competition on which a betting syndicate thrives. Criminals fight in boxing matches with very lax rules, thus making it a very addictive and lucrative venture for the syndicate. The most popular boxer behind bars is Sweetwater's undefeated Monroe Hutchens (Snipes), who ends up in solitary confinement after Chambers picks a fight with him in the mess hall. Sensing the brewing hatred for the heavyweight champion, an incarcerated mob boss named Ripstein (Falk) senses potential in a match between the modest Hutchens and the egomaniacal Chambers. Ripstein, a lifelong boxing fan, proposes a match and the warden (Arndt) is persuaded to look the other way. As all the arrangements are finally organized, an eagerly awaited fight night arrives. All hell breaks loose with the haughty professional champ going all out against the unputdownable prison warrior. Chambers knocks down Hutchens twice (and with the 'London Prize' format, each knockdown counts as the end of a round, as the boxer is given only 60 seconds to get up.) In the third round, Hutchens charges back and knocks Chambers down for the first time in his career, sending the crowd of prisoners into a frenzy. Finally, in the fourth round Hutchens officially KO's Chambers to become the undisputed champion. Ripstein's Mexican assistant reveals in a voice over that Ripstein died three weeks after the fight, but in his will, he left him $2,000,000. Chambers was released on parole, and Hutchens received the money for his sister, who was experiencing hardship on the outside. It is also revealed that Chambers and his manager denied that the fight with Hutchens ever occurred, and that it was all a rumor. Months later, Chambers wins back the Heavyweight Championship of the World. The whole cell block watches the televised fight, and laugh and cheer Monroe's name after hearing Chambers being crowned the 'undisputed' heavyweight champion of the world. ==Cast== * [[Wesley Snipes]] as Monroe "Undisputed" Hutchens * [[Ving Rhames]] as George "Iceman" Chambers * [[Peter Falk]] as Mendy Ripstein * [[Michael Rooker]] as A.J. Mercker * [[Jon Seda]] as Jesus 'Chuy' Campos * [[Wes Studi]] as Mingo Pace * [[Fisher Stevens]] as Ratbag Dolan * [[Master P]] as Gat Boyz Rapper 1 * [[Silkk the Shocker]] as Gat Boyz Rapper 2 * [[C-Murder]] as Gat Boyz Rapper 3 * [[Ed Lover]] as Marvin Bonds * [[Dayton Callie]] as Yank Lewis * Dennis Arndt as the Warden * [[Bruce A. Young]] as Charles Soward ==Production== ===Development=== The film was based on an original script by Walter Hill and David Giler. Hill had just come off the science fiction film ''Supernova'' on which he had been recut by [[Francis Ford Coppola]] among others. "One, it was embarrassing and, two, it made me think about quitting," said Hill. "While Coppola's intentions were honorable, I think he made a bad situation worse. I didn't do anything for a year. I was fortunate enough that I could buy my children a hot lunch. Then, I decided I wanted to work again."{{cite news|title='Undisputed' director Walter Hill still is king of the ring|last=Lovell|first= Glenn|newspaper= Knight Ridder Tribune News Service|date=26 Aug 2002|page= 1}} Hill had always wanted to make a boxing film, being a fan of the sport since he was young. "Boxing is easy to indict," says Hill. "There are a lot of terrible things about boxing. However, that's only one side of the coin. The other side is that boxing has a power and a beauty and a drama and fascination that makes it a very compelling sport." Hill and Giler were having lunch one day and discussed Mike Tyson, who was sentenced to prison for rape in 1992. Giler said they thought "it's amazing how no studio has made a film out of this basic situation of the heavyweight champion of the world going to prison, the toughest environment in the world," said Giler. Hill went and wrote some paragraphs about the idea then he and Giler wrote a full script. However Hill says while the Tyson case was the departure point, "There are a number of prize fighters who have been in trouble with the law. Our story looks at how a tough guy and celebrity would handle life in prison. The more we wrote, the more we wrote away from the Tyson story."{{cite news|title=AN ACTOR BOXES BEHIND BARS IN `UNDISPUTED'|first=Angela|last= Dawson|newspaper=Boston Globe|date=18 Aug 2002|page= L.12}} Hill says he was really interested in what happened when "a heavyweight champion goes to the toughest environment possible in American culture, the American prison system."{{cite news|title=Cornerman; Emanual Steward, trainer of 29 world champions, prepares Wesley Snipes to fight in 'Undisputed.'|last=Holmes|first= Emory|newspaper= Los Angeles Times |date=21 Aug 2002|page= F.1.}} "What we tried to show is how, under odd circumstances, a convicted murderer and a convicted rapist are capable of a moment of grace," said Hill. "They're both heroic." The film refuses to say if the champion boxer was actually guilty. "It is absolutely ambiguous in this movie, ambiguous in the sense that it is very clear that he believes himself to be innocent. It is also absolutely clear that the woman involved believes herself to have been abused and raped... If you want to know what I suspect, I suspect they're both right. It has to do with different terms, different values and different understanding of the basic compact when men and women go to bed together." ===Casting=== Hill said the film needed to be cast with black actors to have "serious credibility," and that he "was determined not to have a movie where it looked like the actors couldn't box." He took the treatment to [[Wesley Snipes]] who was interested in the story even before the script had been written. "I told him it was conceivable that he could play either [lead] role, but what will not change is the fight and who wins in the end," Hill said. Hill then sent the script to [[Ving Rhames]], who called back the next day, saying he wanted to play the Ice Man; Snipes was happy to play the other role. Rhames was in peak physical condition having been preparing for two years to star in a film about [[Sonny Liston]], ''Night Train'', that ultimately was never made. He said that ''Undisputed'' was "not ''[[Rocky]]''... It's not clear-cut who you're supposed to root for." He had worked together with Snipes on Broadway earlier, the last time in 1986 in ''The Boys of Winter''. It was a battle to get the film financed with two black stars, particularly as the film need to appeal to international audiences. "There was a lot of pressure to change one of the characters to be white," Giler said, "but we thought it would be unrealistic... We haven't seen a white fighter of merit since [[Rocky Marciano]]."{{cite news|title=It was a battle to get Undisputed... |last=Portman|first= Jamie|newspaper= CanWest News |date=28 Aug 2002|page= 1}} Hill said that "heavyweight boxing within the past 50 years has been the purview of black men with a couple of tiny exceptions. This is a movie about boxing so we wanted to get it right. I think that the idea of the heavyweight champion of the world not being a black man would seem extraordinary. But if you did cast a black man as the heavyweight champion and then out him into a prison where the prison champion is white guy - well, what are we talking about?" There was also pressure to make the film less "tough". Snipes recalled, "The film was on. It was off. The money came. The money fell out. Every day, it was a wonder we were making this movie. Then, after we made the film, nobody knew whether it was ever going to come out." He prepared for the role by training with Emanuel Steward, who had trained 29 world champions, including [[Tommy Hearns]] and [[Lennox Lewis]]. "[My character] was supposed to be the best," Snipes said, "so if I've got to look like the best, and live up to this character, I've got to get the best and work with the best." Rhames was already in peak condition due to preparing for the aborted Liston film; the film's fight choreographer Cole McKay took over training of Rhames once filming began. ===Shooting=== The movie was going to be filmed in a closed-down prison in Jean, Nevada. However, according to Jeanne Corcoran, the Nevada Film Office's production manager, the prison "didn't have the right look. It has a great fence, a good tower, but the interiors tend to be more dormitory-like." Instead it was decided to shoot the film in an unopened wing of the medium-security High Desert State Prison in Indian Springs, Nevada.{{cite news|title="Undisputed" to battle with Snipes, Rhames|last=Cling|first= Carol|newspaper= Las Vegas Review - Journal |date=22 Jan 2001|page= 5E}} Shooting took place in January and February 2001. The film was shot over 39 days with finance raised from a number of American and European companies. During the final fight, Snipes weighed only 178 pounds while Rhames was around 220 pounds. To mask the disparity, fight choreographer Cole McKay had Snipes fight upright and Rhames hunch forward in a crouching stance. For the final fight, Snipes said he and McKay would "choreograph six or seven movements and then we'd improvise. We improvised the tail-end of each round, and that gave a certain amount of spontaneity and reality to it." Neither actor used a body double, and all of the body shots are real. "Everybody on the set was wanting to see, 'Man who's going to win the fight?' " Steward recalls. "There were no 'John Wayne punches' in this movie at all. It was the closest that I have ever saw to real fightin'. I was mad because we didn't have [someone] to knock out for real." Hill later said, "Some say Hollywood movies that are made about boxing are just metaphors for other things, I think I've made one that's actually about boxing and not a metaphor."[http://www.webwombat.com.au/entertainment/movies/walterhill_int.htm Clint Morris, "Undisputed: Interview with Walter Hill", ''Webwombat''] accessed 25 May 2014 ===Post-production=== Distribution rights were purchased by Miramax Pictures for a reported $4.5 million.{{cite news |title='Signs' crops up as leader of field|last= Fuson|first= Brian|newspaper= Hollywood Reporter|date=26 August 2002|page= 1}} There were press reports that Miramax head [[Harvey Weinstein]] wanted additional scenes reshot which made Wesley Snipes more sympathetic, but that Snipes refused to do them.{{cite news|title=SNIPES MAY SUFFER RESHOOTING PAINS|newspaper= New York Daily News|date=19 Feb 2002|page= 24}} ==Reception== The film received mixed reviews. [[Rotten Tomatoes]] gives the film a score of 48% based on reviews from 104 critics. The site's consensus is: While not the deepest boxing movie out there, Undisputed is successful at hitting its aspiration of being nothing more than a genre picture.{{cite web | url = https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/undisputed/ | title = Undisputed (2002) | work = [[Rotten Tomatoes]] | publisher = [[Flixster]] }} Hill said he was "very happy about" the film. "I mean no film is beyond criticism, but I think we've made a very modest movie. Heck, we did it in 39 days, it cost $20 million, which is very cheap for Hollywood standards, and tells a good story. I guess it's the literary equivalent of a short story... With all the action in it and the tough guy aspects, it's going to appeal mainly to a young male audience. But, also the nostalgia of the sport might appeal to older males. Based on some of the reviews I've read already, the women don't seem to be enjoying it as much. But you hope for the best." The film debuted at number 8 at the box office making $4.7 million in its first week. ==Soundtrack== {{main|Undisputed (soundtrack)}} A soundtrack containing [[hip hop music]] was released on March 5, 2002 by [[Universal Records]]. It peaked at #101 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] and #41 on the [[Top R&B/Hip-Hop Albums]]. ==Sequels== The film received three [[direct-to-video]] [[sequel]]s. The first was ''[[Undisputed II: Last Man Standing]]'', which was released in 2006. A second sequel, ''[[Undisputed III: Redemption]]'', was released in 2010, and follows ''Undisputed II''{{'}}s Yuri Boyka as the main character. A third sequel, again focusing on the latter character, ''[[Boyka: Undisputed]]'', was released in 2016. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.miramax.com/movie/undisputed}} * {{IMDb title|0281322|Undisputed}} * {{amg title|259826|Undisputed}} * {{mojo title|undisputed|Undisputed}} {{Walter Hill}} [[Category:2002 films]] [[Category:2000s drama films]] [[Category:2000s martial arts films]] [[Category:2000s sports films]] [[Category:African-American films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American martial arts films]] [[Category:American sports films]] [[Category:Boxing films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films scored by Stanley Clarke]] [[Category:Films directed by Walter Hill]] [[Category:Films produced by Wesley Snipes]] [[Category:Films set in the Las Vegas Valley]] [[Category:Films set in prison]] [[Category:American gangster films]] [[Category:Prison films]] [[Category:Screenplays by Walter Hill]] [[Category:Films produced by Walter Hill]]

{{more citations needed|date=March 2017}} {{Infobox gymnast |name= Yana Lukonina |gender= |image= Луконина, Яна Олеговна.jpg |image_size= |caption= |fullname= Yana Olegovna Lukonina |altname= |nickname= Yanochka |country= {{flagu|Russia}} |regions= |formercountry= |birth_date= {{birth date and age|1993|9|26|df=y}} |birth_place= [[Ryazan]], [[Ryazan Oblast]], [[Russia]] |hometown= |residence= [[Moscow]], Russia |death_date= |death_place= |height= 172 cm |weight= 50 kg |discipline= RG |level= Senior International Elite |natlteam= |club= |gym= |collegeteam= |headcoach= [[Irina Viner]] |assistcoach= [[Amina Zaripova]] |formercoach= |choreographer= |music= |eponymousskills= |retired= 2012 |worldranking= |updated= |show-medals = yes |medaltemplates = <!-- see [[Template:MedalRelatedTemplates]] --> {{MedalCountry|{{RUS}}}} {{MedalSport|[[Rhythmic Gymnastics]]}} {{MedalCompetition|[[World Rhythmic Gymnastics Championships|World Championships]]}} {{MedalGold|[[2010 World Rhythmic Gymnastics Championships|2010 Moscow]] | Team}} }} '''Yana Olegovna Lukonina''' ({{lang-ru|Яна Олеговна Луконина}}; born 26 September 1993 in [[Ryazan]], [[Ryazan Oblast]], [[Russia]]) is a retired Russian individual [[rhythmic gymnast]]. She is the [[Russian Rhythmic Gymnastics Championships|2010 Russian National]] all-around bronze medalist.
== Career == Lukonina relocated to Novogorsk at 12 years old and began training under [[Amina Zaripova]]. She became the [[2008 Rhythmic Gymnastics European Championships|2008 European Junior champion]] in ball held in [[Torino]], Italy and also won the Junior Team gold medal.
Lukonina debuted in senior at the 2010 Season, she competed at the [[Rhythmic Gymnastics World Cup|2010 Montreal World Cup]] finishing 10th in all-around and won silver in ribbon finals. Lukonina finished 6th in all-around at the [[Rhythmic Gymnastics World Cup|2010 St. Petersburg World Cup]]. She then won the all-around bronze medal at the [[Russian Rhythmic Gymnastics Championships|2010 Russian Championships]]. She won silver in ribbon and finished 4th in ribbon finals at the [[Rhythmic Gymnastics World Cup|2010 Corbeil-Essonnes World Cup]] and finished 10th in the all-around at the [[Rhythmic Gymnastics World Cup|2010 Pesaro World Cup]]. Lukonina was selected as part of the Russian Team for the [[2010 World Rhythmic Gymnastics Championships|2010 World Championships]] held in [[Moscow]] where she won the gold medal in the team event (together with [[Evgenia Kanaeva]], [[Daria Kondakova]] and [[Daria Dmitrieva]]).
Lukonina competed at the [[Rhythmic Gymnastics World Cup|2011 Montreal World Cup]] along with [[Margarita Mamun]], Lukonina won gold in hoop and bronze medals in clubs and ribbon. She then won the all-around bronze at the [[Rhythmic Gymnastics World Cup|2011 Kiev World Cup]]. Lukonina suffered a serious back injury and decided to complete her career in the 2012 Season.<ref>{{cite web|title= Яна Луконина: "Заниматься с детьми - одно удовольствие" |url=http://r-gymnastics.com/yana-lukonina-zanimatsya-s-detmi-odno-udovolstvie |publisher=r-gymnastics |date=15 May 2012}}.</ref>
==References== <references/>
==External links== * {{Fig|id=8726|name=Yana Lukonina}} * [http://r-gymnastics.com/yana-lukonina-zanimatsya-s-detmi-odno-udovolstvie Yana Lukonina Profile] * [http://www.rhythmicgymnasticsresults.com/ Rhythmic Gymnastics Results]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Lukonina, Yana}} [[Category:1993 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Russian rhythmic gymnasts]] [[Category:People from Ryazan]] [[Category:Rhythmic gymnast stubs]] [[Category:Medalists at the Rhythmic Gymnastics World Championships]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Yurcak Field | nickname = | image = Sky Blue FC players warm-up before the game 2011.jpg | fullname = The Soccer Stadium at Yurcak Field | location = 83 Fitch Rd.
[[Piscataway, NJ]] 08854 | coordinates = {{coord|40|31|6.7224|N|74|27|49.3632|W|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | opened = 1994 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey]] | operator = Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey | surface = [[Grass]] | dimensions = 120 x 75 yards | construction_cost = $28 million + $102 million expansion | tenants = [[Rutgers University|Rutgers]] [[Rutgers Scarlet Knights|Scarlet Knights]] ([[NCAA]])
men's and women's soccer (1994-present)
[[Rutgers Scarlet Knights men's lacrosse|men's]] and women's lacrosse (1994-2013)
[[New Jersey Pride]] ([[Major League Lacrosse|MLL]]) (2006–2008)
[[Sky Blue FC]] ([[Women's Professional Soccer|WPS]]/[[National Women's Soccer League|NWSL]])
(2009–2011, 2013–present) | seating_capacity = 5,000 |}} '''Yurcak Field''' is a 5,000 seat [[soccer-specific stadium]] on the main campus of [[Rutgers-New Brunswick|Rutgers University]] in [[Piscataway Township, New Jersey|Piscataway Township]], [[New Jersey]]. Fully acknowledged as '''The Soccer Stadium at Yurcak Field''', it is named in honor of Ronald N. Yurcak, a 1965 All-American Rutgers Lacrosse player. The stadium opened in 1994. The stadium is the official home of the [[Rutgers Scarlet Knights]] men's and women's soccer teams{{cite web|last=Rutgers University Scarlet Knights |title=Yurcak Field |url=http://www.scarletknights.com/sports/2017/6/11/facilities-yurcak-html.aspx |publisher=Rutgers University Scarlet Knights |date=June 11, 2017|accessdate=August 7, 2017}} and [[Sky Blue FC]] of the [[National Women's Soccer League]].{{cite web|url=http://www.skybluefc.com/tickets/stadium/|title=Stadium|publisher=Sky Blue FC|date=August 7, 2017}} It was the home of the Rutgers [[Rutgers Scarlet Knights men's lacrosse|men's]] and women's lacrosse teams from 1994 until 2013 when the Scarlet Knights' lacrosse teams moved to nearby [[HighPoint.com Stadium]].{{cite web|url=https://www.onthebanks.com/2017/5/3/15487470/rutgers-lacrosse-is-a-good-draw-big-ten-lacrosse-attendance|title=Rutgers lacrosse is a good draw|publisher=onthebanks.com|date=May 3, 2017|accessdate=August 7, 2017}} In 1999, Yurcak Field hosted a third round match of the [[1999 Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cup]] between the [[Staten Island Vipers]] of the [[A-League (1995–2004)|A-League]] and the MetroStars, now the [[New York Red Bulls]], of [[Major League Soccer]].{{cite web|url=http://www.funwhileitlasted.net/2013/10/01/july-13-1999-staten-island-vipers-vs-metrostars/|title=July 13, 1999 – Staten Island Vipers vs. MetroStars|website=funwhileitlasted.net|date=October 1, 2013|accessdate=August 23, 2017}} In 2003, the stadium hosted two matches of the [[2003 Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cup]]. A quarter-final match between the [[New England Revolution]] and the MetroStars and a semi-final match between [[D.C. United]] and the MetroStars with the MetroStars winning both matches.{{cite web|url=http://www.soccertimes.com/proleagues/usopencup/2003/games/aug27.htm|title=Guevara's goal late in sudden death sends MetroStars past New England 2-1.|publisher=soccertimes.com|date=August 27, 2003|accessdate=August 11, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061214144656/http://soccertimes.com/proleagues/usopencup/2003/games/aug27.htm#|archive-date=2006-12-14|dead-url=yes|df=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.onceametro.com/2017/7/14/15971564/2017-us-open-cup-semi-final-finals-hosting-draw|title=2017 US Open Cup Semi-Final & Finals hosting Draw|publisher=onceametro.com|date=July 14, 2017|accessdate=August 11, 2017}} The facility has hosted the Division II & III [[NCAA Men's Lacrosse Championship]] games in 1998, 2001, and 2002. It was also the home the [[New Jersey Pride]] of [[Major League Lacrosse]] from 2006 through 2008. In June 2015, it was announced that Yurcak Field would receive enhanced locker rooms, a new training room and new general office space in the coming years as part of a campus wide program to upgrade Rutgers athletic facilities.{{cite web|url=https://www.app.com/story/sports/college/rutgers/2015/06/18/rutgers-unveils-athletic-facilities-plan-bog/28937999/|title=Rutgers unveils plan for new and updated athletics facilities|publisher=app.com|date=June 18, 2015|accessdate=October 9, 2018}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.scarletknights.com/sports/2017/6/11/facilities-yurcak-html.aspx Yurcak Field, Rutgers University] {{Rutgers|New Brunswick}} {{Big Ten Conference navbox}} {{Sky Blue FC}} {{National Women's Soccer League stadiums}} {{NewYorksportsvenues}} {{NewJerseysports}} [[Category:Rutgers Scarlet Knights]] [[Category:Sky Blue FC]] [[Category:Sky Blue FC (NWSL)]] [[Category:Women's Professional Soccer stadiums]] [[Category:National Women's Soccer League stadiums]] [[Category:Soccer venues in New Jersey]] [[Category:College soccer venues in the United States]] [[Category:Lacrosse venues in the United States]] [[Category:College lacrosse venues in the United States]] [[Category:Sports venues in New Jersey]] [[Category:Sports venues in the New York metropolitan area]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in the United States]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Middlesex County, New Jersey]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Middlesex County, New Jersey]] [[Category:Piscataway, New Jersey]] [[Category:1994 establishments in New Jersey]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1994]] {{NewJersey-stadium-stub}}
